You can file an injured spouse's claim using Form 8379 "Payment to an Innocent Spouse" or Form 8857 "Request for Exemption from Taxes, Interest, and Fines" to recover part or all of the joint refund amount transferred to pay your spouse's individual liabilities.

The IRS will not pay returns filed for an earned income tax credit or a child tax credit earlier than mid-February 2025, not just for the portion of the refund related to the said tax credits, but for the full amount of the refund.

If you have a tax debt on your return, you must pay it by the tax filing deadline (regardless of extensions) to avoid penalties and late payment interest. Your tax debt for the calendar year 2024 must be paid by April 15, 2025. You can make payments in a variety of ways, including by scheduled electronic debit from a checking or savings account, or by debit or credit card. For more information on payment methods, please visit IRS.gov/Payments.
You will need to complete Form 8879, "Right to Sign Tax Returns Filed Electronically with the IRS," to give the professional permission to enter your self-selected PIN on the tax return.

IRS has developed electronic versions of tax forms, which can also be filed in electronic format for free. Free File tax return system electronic forms will be the best solution for those who prepare their own tax return. There are no income limits to use these forms. Free File tax return system electronic forms can make basic calculations. Tikai Federal tax forms būti available.

If you are filing a tax return for a fiscal year (see explanation in chapter 2), you must file your tax return by the 15th of the fourth month after the end of your fiscal year. Penalties and interest may be applied if you fail to file your tax return on time. If you are unable to file your tax return on time, file Form 4868, Application for an Automatic Extension of the U.S. Individual Income Tax Return, to request an automatic extension of the tax return deadline by 6 months. If you file your tax return for a calendar year using this form, you will be able to extend the deadline to October 15.

Federal income tax is paid on current income. You must pay income tax on income or wages received during the year. As a rule, income tax is withheld from wages for employees. If no tax is withheld from your wages, or if the amount withheld is insufficient, you may be required to pay a deduction.

Generally, you must pay a deduction if you plan to owe taxes, including self-employment tax (see below), of $1,000 or more on your tax return. Use Form 1040-ES to calculate and pay this tax. If you are not required to pay a deduction, you can pay any tax debts on your tax return. For more information on deduction, see Publication No. 505.

If insufficient income tax and self-employment tax was deducted from your salary in 2024, or if you paid insufficient deductible tax, you may be liable to a fine for the amount not paid. In this case, the IRS will calculate the fine and send you an invoice. You can also use Form 2210, "Deductible Tax Deductions by Individuals, Estates and Trusts" to check for a penalty due and calculate the amount of the penalty. For more information, see Publication No. 505.

The self-employed tax is a social security and Medicare tax that is mainly levied on individuals who work for themselves. This tax is similar to the social security and Medicare tax that is withheld from the wages of most employees. If you have earned income as an employee, you are not required to pay self-employed tax on such income. Social security and Medicare taxes are already withheld from such income.

For 2024, you received one of the maximum four credits for every $1,730 ($1,810 in 2025) of income taxable to the Social Security Fund. Thus, if in 2024 you received income (from self-employment and as a wage) of $6,920 taxable to the Social Security Fund, you will receive four credits ($6,920 ÷ $1,730). Find out the number of credits needed to receive insurance and social security benefits for yourself and your relatives at the nearest Social Security Office. False statements made in order to receive or increase the amount of payments from the Social Security Fund may be subject to a fine.

As a rule, the Social Security Office only grants a credit if the self-employment income is reported in a tax return filed within 3 years, 3 months and 15 days after the tax year in which the income was received. If you file a tax return or notify changes in the self-employment income after the expiry of this period, the Social Security Office will only accept a cancellation or reduction of the income. u The Social Security Office will not make any upward changes in your self-employment income.
The self-employed tax rate on net profits is 15.3 per cent (12.4 per cent Social Security tax plus 2.9 per cent Medicare tax)i.

In 2024, only the first 168,600 U.S. dollars, which is the sum of wages, tips and net profits, is subject to any combination of 12.4% self-employed tax, 2.9% Medicare tax or 1% Medicare tax on railway pension benefits. If the wages and tips you receive as an employee are subject to 12.4% self-employed tax, and your income is at least 168,600 U.S. dollars, you are not required to pay 12.4% self-employed tax on any net profits.

If you have both wages and self-employment income, the amount limit applied to the self-employment income Medicare surcharge is reduced (but not reduced to zero) by the amount of wages subject to the Medicare surcharge. Use Form 8959, Medicare Surcharge, to calculate the surcharge.

For more information, see Publication No. 15 (Circular E) “Employer Taxation Guide”. This publication lists your tax liabilities as an employer. Do not deduct the amount of the non-refundable and refundable portions of the eligible sick leave and family leave credits received under the Families First Coronavirus Relief Act and the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 and reported on your employer’s tax return. Instead, report these credits as income. To determine whether people working for your company are your employees, see Publication No. 15-A. This publication contains information that will help you determine whether an individual is an independent contractor or an employee. If you incorrectly declare an employee as an independent contractor, you may be liable to pay tax on that employee plus a penalty.
For more detailed information on excise duties, see Publication No. 510 “Excise Duties” (in Latvian).

The federal excise duty, which must be reported on the Form 720, Quarterly Federal Excise Tax Return, includes several categories of taxes, including the following: Environmental protection tax on the sale or use of ozone-depleting substances and imported products containing or made using such substances.

The use of certain types of heavy duty vehicles, tractors and buses on public roads is subject to federal excise duty. This tax applies to vehicles with a gross taxable weight of 55,000 pounds (25,000 kg) or more. This tax must be reported on Form 2290, Heavy Duty Road Vehicle Tax Return. For more information, see the Form 2290 instructions.

If you make or receive payments in the course of your business, you may be required to file a disclosure return with the IRS. To verify the presence of payments in your income, the IRS compares the payments listed in your disclosure return with each person's income tax return.

Regardless of the amount of the payment, you must also file a Form 1099-NEC for each person from whom you have withheld any federal income tax (report in box 4) under the additional withholding tax rules. If you are completing a Form 1099-NEC for a report on sales of consumer goods totalling $5,000 or more, you must file this form with the IRS by January 31.

The following forms are subject to fines: Form 1099-MISC, Form 1099-NEC or Form W-2. There are also fines for providing incorrect information. For more information, see the general instructions for certain disclosure forms.

If you can prove that the violation was committed for reasonable reasons and not due to intentional negligence, you will be exempted from fines. Furthermore, for not including all the required information or for providing incorrect information in a de minimis (insignificant) number of informational declarations when correcting errors before August 1 of the year in which the declarations are required, no fine is imposed. (De minimis is 10 declarations or half of 1% of the total number of declarations (whichever is greater) that you must file for that year.)
You must file Form 8300, "Report of Cash Payments Over $10,000" received by a merchant or company if you received more than $10,000 in cash payments for one or more commercial transactions.

You must calculate your taxable income and file a tax return for the annual reporting period called the tax year. In addition, you must consistently use a reporting method that clearly shows your income and expenses for the tax year.

If you do not have a mandatory tax year, you choose a tax year when you file your first tax return for that tax year. A mandatory tax year is a tax year that is required by the Tax Code or by the Income Tax Regulations.

If you filed your first tax return for a calendar tax year and later start a business as a sole proprietor, you must continue to use a calendar tax year unless you obtain IRS permission to change it or are allowed to change it without IRS permission. For more information, see the section "Changes to Tax Year" below. If you have chosen a calendar tax year, you must keep books and reports and report your income and expenses for the period from January 1 to December 31 of each year.

A fiscal tax year is 12 consecutive months ending on the last day of any month except December. A 52-53-week tax year is a fiscal tax year that varies from 52 to 53 weeks, but does not necessarily end on the last day of the month. If you choose a fiscal tax year, you must keep accounting documents and records and report your income and expenses using the same tax year. For more information on a fiscal tax year, including a 52-53-week tax year, see Publication No. 538.
You must use the same accounting method for calculating your taxable income and keeping accounting records.

Some taxpayers may assume that they have permission from the IRS to change their accounting method. Permission is granted for the tax year for which the taxpayer requests the change (the change year) if the taxpayer complies with the provisions of the automatic change procedure. For an application filed under the automatic change procedure, mainly described in Tax Procedure 2015-13, 2015-5 I.R.B, 419 (or later), and available at IRS.gov/IRB/2015-05_IRB#RP-2015-13, no fee is required.

You can keep accounts of business and personal income and expenses using different accounting methods. For example, you can calculate your business income on an accrual basis, even if you use the cash method for calculating personal income and expenses.

If you have two or more separate and distinct lines of business, you may use different accounting methods for each if the method clearly reflects the income of each line. They are separate and distinct only if you keep complete and distinct documents and records for each line.

In the cash method, include in your gross income all items of income that you actually or supposedly receive during the tax year. If you receive property or services, you must include their fair market value in income.

You have implied income when the amount is credited to your account or provided to you without restrictions. You do not have to own it. If you have appointed someone as your agent, you are deemed to have received the income when your agent received it.

If your debts are paid by another person or cancelled by your creditors, you may have to declare part or all of the cancelled debt as income. If you receive income in this way, you are supposedly receiving income when the debt is cancelled or paid. For more information, see the section “Repaid debt” in the section “Types of income” in Chapter 5.

If you include a certain amount in your income and need to refund it in full or in part in the following year, you can generally deduct the amount of the refund in the year you made it. If the amount you refund exceeds $3,000, a special rule applies. For details on the special rule, see “Refunds” in Chapter 8 of Publication No. 17.

Under the accrual method, you usually report income in the year in which it is earned and deduct or capitalize expenses in the year in which they are incurred. The purpose of accrual accounting is to compare income and expenses for the year in question.

When using the accrual method, you usually include an amount in your gross income for the tax year in which all the events determining your entitlement to income occurred and you can determine that amount with reasonable accuracy. For a taxpayer with a proper financial statement or other financial statement prepared in accordance with the regulations of the Ministry of Finance, the “all events” test for a gross income item is deemed to be met no later than when it is recognized in the proper financial statement or other similar financial statement.

If you include a reasonably estimated amount in gross income and later determine that the exact amount is different, take into account the difference in the tax year in which you determine the amount.

If you provide services at the base rate specified in the contract, you must accrue income at the base rate, even if you agree to receive payments at a lower rate, until you complete the services and then receive the differencel.

You usually report the advance payment as income in the year you receive it. However, if you receive an advance payment, you may defer the inclusion of the advance payment in income until the next tax year. You cannot defer the inclusion of any payment until the next tax year. For more information, see Publication No. 538 and Section 451.

When the production, purchase or sale of goods is a factor in your business, you generally have to keep inventory records at the beginning and end of the tax year, unless you are a small business taxpayer.

You cannot deduct business expenses and interest due to a dependent person who uses the cash method of accounting until you make the payment and the amount is included in the gross income of the dependent person. Determine the degree of relationship for this rule at the end of the tax year in which the expenses or interest would otherwise be deductible. If the deduction is not allowed under this rule, the rule will continue to apply even if your relationship with the person ceases before the expenses or interest are included in that person's gross income.

If you are a small business owner, you may not include inventory in your assets, but you should still use an accounting method for inventory that clearly reflects income. If you choose not to include inventory in your assets, this will not be a sign of failure to clearly reflect income if your accounting method treats MTS (materials and stocks) as planned materials or stocks or if it is consistent with your financial accounting for inventory. However, if you choose to include inventory in your assets, you should generally use the accrual method and assess the inventory each year to determine the value of goods sold in Part III of Annex C.

You are considered a small business owner if you (a) have an average annual gross income of $30 million or less for the 3 previous tax years and (b) are not a tax haven (as defined in section 448(d)(3)).

You must assess your MTFs at the beginning and end of each tax year to determine the value of the goods sold (Annex C, line 42). To assess the value of your MTFs, you need a method of identifying the items of income and expenditure in your MTFs and a method of measuring those items.

You may fall under the uniform capitalization rules if you engage in one of the following activities, except where the property is for personal use and not for business or activities carried out for the purpose of making a profit. The production of immovable or tangible personal property. In this context, tangible personal property includes a film, sound recording, videotape, book or similar property. Acquisition of real estate for resale.

There are special methods for accounting for certain items of income or expense. These include the following methods. Depreciation of intangible assets, discussed in Chapter 7 of Publication No. 225. Bad debts, discussed in Topic No. 453 “Write-off of bad debt”. Depletion, discussed in Chapter 7 of Publication No. 225. Depreciation, discussed in Publication No. 946 “How to depreciate property”. Sale on instalment, discussed in Publication No. 537 “Sale on instalment”. Long-term contractual accounting methods. See Section 460.

Instead, all the assets of the business are sold. In this case, each asset is treated as a separate sale for the purposes of determining profit or loss. The buyer and seller involved in the sale of the business must report to the IRS on the distribution of the sale price among the assets of the business.

The amount of the sale of property is defined as the total amount of money you received plus the fair market value of all the property or services you received. The amount of the sale also includes all your liabilities that the buyer assumes and all liabilities in respect of the property you have transferred, such as property taxes or mortgages.

The fair market value of a property is defined as the price at which it passes from the seller to the buyer, provided that both parties are not under any coercion and are reasonably aware of all the necessary facts.

Your income or loss from the disposal of property is usually recognised as income or loss for tax purposes. The recognised income must be included in gross income. The recognised loss may be deducted from gross income. However, in some cases, the income or loss from certain property exchange transactions is not recognised. See the section “Non-taxable transactions” presented above.
If you have received a profit or loss from the sale of a capital asset, you must determine whether it is a short-term or long-term profit or loss.
To provide this information, you may need to file Form 6252, Income from Sale on Installment.

This credit applies to the initial cost of a new qualifying defined benefit or defined contribution (including 401(k)) pension plan, SIMPLE plan or SEP plan. For more information, see Publication No. 560, Small Business Pension Plans.

This non-refundable tax credit is available to small businesses that pay for physical access for people with reduced mobility. To comply with the Disability Protection Act of 1990, you must pay for the cost of physical access. For more information, see Form 8826.
This credit applies to qualified railway maintenance expenses paid or incurred during the tax year. For more information, see Form 8900.

This chapter explains what business income is, how to account for it for tax purposes, and what income is not considered income. This also provides guidance for people who are engaged in certain activities. If there is a link between your business and the income you receive, then that income is considered to be business. The link exists if it is obvious that there would be no income if you did not own the business. You can have business income even if you do not take a regular part in the activities of your business. u Income from a side job in addition to your main job can be business income. u For example, you can provide services to a company that provides a ride-sharing service as a second job. u Most income from individual business activities, such as income from the sale of goods or services, must be reported in ru ru but income from the sale of company assets, such as land and office buildings, must be reported in other forms. ru For more information about selling company assets, see ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru ru

Income from business activities includes amounts you received in the course of your individual business activities and that you reported on Forms 1099-NEC. This includes the amounts reported in box 1 of the said form as payments under a civil contract.

Name, Image, Likeness (NIL) is a term used to describe the means by which student athletes are allowed to receive financial compensation. NIL can be classified as self-employment income. If your NIL income exceeds $600 from any source, including non-cash income, you will receive a Form 1099-NEC or Form 1099-MISC containing the amount of income you must report on your tax return.

If you are a sole proprietor, you may obtain a Form 1099-K that shows the total amount in dollars of all reportable payments. This may not be the amount you should report as income, as it may not include all income, but may include items that are not included in your income (for example, sales tax).

The income you declared on Schedule C may be qualified individual business income and entitle you to a deduction on Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR (line 13). See Form 8995-A or Form 8995 to determine the amount of the deduction.

In most cases, individual business income is received in the form of cash, checks and credit card payments. However, individual business income may also come in other forms, such as property or services. These and other types of income are explained below. If you are a U.S. citizen who receives individual business income from sources outside the United States (abroad income), you must report that income on your tax return unless it is exempt from tax under U.S. law. If you are resident outside the United States, you are entitled to deduct all or part of the foreign individual business income from your tax base. For more information, see Publication 54, Tax Guidelines for U.S. Citizens and Foreign Residents Living Abroad.

If you are a real estate agent who receives income from renting out property, or a hotel, motel, etc. owner who provides certain services to guests (maid services, etc.), you must report your rental income and expenses in Schedule C. If you are not a real estate agent or such an entrepreneur as described in the previous sentence, report your rental income and expenses in Schedule E. For more information, see Publication No. 527 “Residential Property for Rent”.

You are a real estate agent if you sell real estate to clients with the aim of making a profit from these sales. The rent for real estate that you hold for sale to clients is subject to SE tax. However, the rent for real estate that you hold for speculative purposes or as an investment is not subject to SE tax.

Rent income from a trailer park is subject to SE taxation if you are a self-employed trailer park owner who rents out premises and parking spaces and provides essential services for the convenience of tenants.

Rent income you receive from the use or occupation of hotels, guesthouses or apartment buildings is subject to SE tax if you provide services to tenants. Generally, you are considered to provide services to tenants if the services are primarily for their convenience and are not services that are usually provided for renting rooms for living only. Examples of services that are not usually provided for the convenience of tenants are maid services. However, heating and lighting, stairs and hallways cleaning, and garbage removal are services that are usually provided for the convenience of tenants.

If you rent out personal property (equipment, vehicles, official clothing, etc.), include the amount of rent you receive in your gross income in Schedule C. Prepaid rent and other payments described in the “Real Estate Rental” section above may also be received for renting out personal property. If you receive any of these payments, include them in your gross income as explained above.

If a loan due becomes uncollectible during the tax year and you are using the accrual method, you should generally include in your gross income the specified unconditionally payable interest accrued prior to the time the loan became uncollectible. If the accrued interest previously included in your income is subsequently uncollectible, you may be eligible for a deduction for uncollectible debts. See the section "Uncollectible Debts" in Chapter 8.

If the interest on the installment sale is low or no interest at all, you may have to treat part of each payment as unstated interest income. See Unstated Interest and Original Issue Discount (OID) in Publication No. 537.

For most sole proprietors and legal employees, however, dividends are not business income. If you have stocks as a personal investment not related to your business, then dividends on stocks are not business income. If you receive dividends on business insurance premiums that you have deducted from the tax base in one of the previous years, you must declare all or part of those dividends on your tax return as business income. To find out what amount you must declare, see the subsection “Refund of Previously Deducted Expenses” in the “Other Income” section below.

If your debt is cancelled or forgiven, unless it is a gift or inheritance, you must generally include the amount written off in your gross income for tax purposes. If the debt is related to business, the amount written off is shown on line 6 of Schedule C. If the debt is not related to business, the amount written off is shown on line 8c of Schedule 1 (Form 1040)u.
You have not realized the income from the cancelled debt if the amount of the debt could have been deducted from the taxable base.

If you are a non-corporate entity (e.g., a single-member LLC), see the Qualified Real Property Business Indebtedness section in Chapter 1 of Publication No. 4681 to see if you qualify for this exclusion. You may not exclude from income an amount that exceeds either of the following items: 1. the outstanding principal of the real estate company’s qualifying debt (immediately prior to cancellation); 2. the fair market value (immediately prior to cancellation) of the company’s real property that is collateralized by the debt, less the outstanding principal of any other qualifying debt of the company secured by that property, immediately prior to cancellation.

To opt-in, complete Form 982 and attach it to your income tax return for the tax year in which the debt was cancelled. You should file your return by the due date (including extensions). If you have already filed a tax return without making an option, you can still do so by filing an amended tax return within 6 months of the due date (excluding extensions). For more information, see the “When to File” section of the form instructions.

If you have received a security package or any other property with restrictions on its value, the fair market value of such property that exceeds the value of your services is included in the income shown in Schedule C after the restriction is removed.
This rule does not apply to depreciation, which is accrued as explained below.
The depreciation deduction must be returned to the state in the following situations. This means that you must include in your income all the amounts of deductions for previous years.

If the use of a registered property (as described in the “Depreciation” section of Chapter 8) has fallen to 50% or less in the tax year following the tax year in which you put the property into operation, you may have to return part of the depreciation deduction for previous years.

If you are making a deduction for the value of an asset under Section 179 (described in the “Depreciation” section of Chapter 8) and the extent of its use for business purposes falls to 50% or less before the end of the refund period, you will be required to refund the portion of the deduction under Section 179. You do this by including in Schedule C income the portion of the deduction that you have declared.

If you have sold or exchanged depreciable property with profit, you must declare all or part of the depreciation gain as ordinary income. How to calculate the depreciation return is described in Part III of Form 4797. For more information, see Chapter 4 of Publication No. 544.

Any rebate you receive is declared as part of income in Annex C. However, rebate should not be included in income if you lawfully report it as a decrease in the relevant expense item, as capital expenditure or as the value of goods soldu.

If you have received a refund of bad debt or any other amount that you have already deducted from your taxable base in a previous year, you must include the amount of the refund in your income on Schedule C. However, if the total or partial amount of the deduction in previous years did not reduce your tax liability, you are entitled to exclude from your income the portion that did not affect your tax liability. If you have deducted from your income part of the refund, you must attach a calculation to your tax return showing how the deduction was calculated.
The increase in the value of your property is not declared as income until you realize it by selling it or disposing of it in another taxable manner.

If a tenant builds new buildings or provides your property with amenities, the improvement in the value of the property due to the amenities is not your income. u However, if the facts indicate that the amenities are deducted from the rent you receive, then the improvement in the value of the property is declared as income.

The transfer of goods to another person for sale on your behalf is not a sale. The ownership of the property remains with the consignor, i.e. with you, even after the consignor takes possession of the goods. Thus, if the goods are shipped for sale on a consignment basis, you cannot declare any profit or loss until the consignor sells the goods. The goods shipped on a consignment basis remain with you in your inventory account until they are sold. The goods you receive on a consignment basis should not be included in your inventory. Include in your income the profit or commission on the sale of the goods that are transferred to you on a consignment basis when you sell the goods or when you receive the profit or commission, depending on your accounting method.

A short-term lease is a contract (or other occupancy or use agreement) for a period of 15 years or less. In determining whether a lease is for a period of 15 years or less, consider whether it provides for the possibility of renewal. However, no provision for renewal at a fair market rate as determined at the time of renewal should be taken into account. Two or more leases in a single transaction (or a series of related transactions) for the same or substantially similar commercial space are considered as one contract.

You must report this income whether or not it is reported to you in the disclosure statement. You are engaged in direct selling if you meet all of the following requirements: 1. You engage in one of the following professional or business activities. 2. You provide or distribute newspapers or store advertisements (including any services directly related to the profession or business) 3.

If you are an options or commodity dealer, your profits and losses from dealership or trading in contracts under section 1256 (regulated futures contracts, foreign exchange contracts, dealership options on stocks, options on other financial instruments and dealership futures contracts on securities) or any other property related to those contracts (e.g., an equity contract to hedge options) are disclosed in Schedule C. For more information, see sections 1256 and 1402(i).

You are a securities or commodity trader if you engage in transactions to buy and sell securities or commodities on your own account. As a securities or commodity trader (including if you have elected to revalue to fair market value under section 475(f) as a securities or commodity trader), the profits and losses from your transactions are not reported in Schedule C. For more information on securities or commodity traders, see Publication No. 550, Investment Income and Expenses and Topic No. 429, Exchange Brokers.

Termination payments for services provided by you as a freelance insurance agent are not included in Schedule C if all of the following conditions apply to you: you were paid after the expiration of your service agreement with the company; you did not provide any services to the company after the termination of the agreement and until the end of the year in which you were paid; you undertook to not compete with the company for at least 1 year from the date of termination of your service agreement; ii the total amount of payments was based primarily on the insurance policies you sold or credited to your account during the last year of your service agreement; ii the extent to which these policies remained valid for any period of time after the termination of your service agreement, or both; ii the amount of payments was in no way dependent on service or on the total earnings for services provided to the company (whether or not your entitlement to payments was determined by the duration of your service; ii ii the amount of payments was determined by the number of years you worked for the company, and the amount of the payments you received for the services you provided to the company, and the amount of the payments you received for the services you provided to the company, and the amount of the payments you received for the services you provided to the company). ii

Income paid by an insurance company to a retired freelance insurance agent as a percentage of the commissions he received before retirement is reported in Annex C. Renewal commissions and deferred commissions on sales of policies before retirement are also usually reported in Annex C. However, renewal commissions paid to the surviving spouse of an insurance agent are not reported in Annex C.

Accounting for income for tax purposes is sometimes different from accounting for financial purposes. This section discusses some of the most common differences that may affect your business transactions. Calculate your business income for the tax year based on your accounting method (see chapter 2).
You must pay tax on all your earned income. You cannot avoid tax by posting your income to a third party s s.

If the purchaser of your property places all or part of the purchase price in an escrow account, no part of that amount can be recognized in gross sales until you receive it as actual or anticipated income, but upon the expiry of the contract and the escrow account agreement, the amount deposited in the account will become taxable income, even if you do not acquire possession of the funds until the following year.

There are two methods of accounting for immediate payment discounts. You can either credit them to a separate discount account or deduct them from the total amount of purchases for the year. Whichever method you use, you must be consistent. If you want to change your method of calculating the value of your inventory, you must file Form 3115. For more information, see the section "Changing the Accounting Method" in Chapter 2.

If you are taking out goods for personal or family use, you must exclude this value from the total amount of goods you have purchased for sale. To do this, you must credit the purchase or sale account with the value of the goods you have taken out for personal use. You must also credit this amount to your current account. The current account is a separate account that you must keep to account for the business income that you withdraw for personal and family expenses. As mentioned above, you also use it to account for the withdrawals of goods for personal or family use. This account is also known as a cash withdrawal account or a personal account.

Direct labour costs are the wages you pay to employees who work all their time directly on the product you produce. These costs also include the portion of the wages you pay to employees who work directly on the product part-time, if you can identify that portion of their wages.

Indirect labor costs are the wages you pay to employees who perform plant-wide functions that are not directly or indirectly related to the production of a commodity but are a necessary part of the production process.

Overhead costs include rent, heating, light, electricity, insurance, depreciation, taxes, maintenance, labor and supervision. Overhead costs that you consider to be direct and necessary production costs are included in the cost of the goods sold l and l
When you subtract the inventory at the end of the year from the cost of goods available for sale, the balance is the cost of goods sold for the tax year.

After you have calculated the gross revenue from your business (Chapter 5) and the cost of the goods sold (Chapter 6), you are ready to calculate the gross profit. You must determine the gross profit before you can deduct any expenses of conducting the business.
To calculate your gross profit, first determine your net revenue. Calculate your net revenue (line 3) in Schedule C by subtracting any refunds and discounts (line 2) from your gross revenue (line 1).

You do not need to calculate the cost of goods sold if the sale of goods is not a factor generating income for your business. Your gross profit equals net revenue (gross revenue minus returns, discounts or other discounts).
This illustration of the Gross Profit section of a retail company’s income statement shows how gross profit is calculated.

At the end of each business day, make sure that your records match the actual cash and credit receipts for the day. You may find it helpful to use cash registers to record receipts. You should also use a proper billing system and maintain a separate bank account for your business.

If you charge a buyer a state sales tax or a local sales tax charged to you as a seller of goods or services, you must include the amount received in gross revenue. If you are required to collect state taxes and local taxes charged to buyers and remit them to the appropriate local or state agencies, you generally do not include these amounts in income.

If you are a retailer or wholesaler, you can check the accuracy of your gross profit. First divide your gross profit by your net revenue. The percentage you get measures the average difference between the cost of the goods sold and the price you pay for them. Then compare this percentage with your margin policy. A small difference between the two percentages or no difference at all means that your gross profit is accurate. A large difference between the two percentages means that you have miscalculated sales, purchases, inventory or other costs. You must determine the reason for the difference.

On average, you set your selling price to make a gross profit of 331/3% on your sales. The net revenue (gross revenue minus returns and discounts) reported in your income statement is $300,000. The cost of the goods sold is $200,000. As a result, your gross profit is $100,000 (300,000 – 200,000).

If your company has income from a source other than the ordinary business activity, enter this income in line 6 of Annex C and add it to the gross profit. The result is the gross business activity income. As an example, you can mention income from an interest-bearing account, income from the sale of scrap metal, income from certain tax credits and refunds for fuel tax, as well as amounts reimbursed for bad debts.
These expenses are called business expenses. They are expenses that are not required to be capitalized or included in the cost of goods sold, but can be deducted in the current year.

SEP, SIMPLE and Qualified Plans are tax-friendly ways to save for retirement. You can deduct the contributions you make for your employees on Schedule C, Line 19. If you are a sole proprietor, you can deduct the contributions you make for yourself on Schedule 1, Line 16 (Form 1040). You can also deduct commission trustees if your contributions to the plan do not cover them. Earnings from contributions are usually not taxable until you or your employees receive payments from the plan. You may also qualify for a tax credit if you start a new Qualified Determined Benefit or Determined Contribution Plan (including a 401(k) plan), SIMPLE plan or SEP plan. For more information on this credit and credits for automatic enrollment and military spouse participation, see Form 8881 and separate instructions. Under some plans, employees may ask you to contribute limited amounts from their wages before taxation. These amounts (and income from them) are usually not taxable until your employees receive payments from the plan. For more information on Small Business Pension Plans, see Publication No. 560.

Rent is any amount you pay for the use of property that you do not own. As a rule, you can only deduct rent as a business expense if the rent is charged for property that you use in your business. If you have or will acquire a share in the property or ownership of the property, you will not be able to deduct the rent. u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u u

You cannot get a rent deduction for unreasonable rent. Usually, the question of reasonableness only arises if you and the tenant are relatives. A rent paid to a relative is reasonable if it is equal to the amount you would pay to a non-relative for the use of the same property.

If you rent your home and use part of it as a place of business, you can deduct the rent you pay for that part, provided you meet the requirements for using the home for commercial purposes. For more information, see the section “Using the home for business purposes” below.

Rent paid in the course of your business activity is generally deducted in the year of payment or accrual. If you pay the rent in advance, you can only deduct the amount that relates to your use of the rented property during the tax year. The remainder of the payment you can only deduct during the period to which it relates.

You can deduct state tax on Schedule C on gross income (as opposed to net income) directly related to your business. You can deduct other local income taxes as well as state income tax on Schedule A (Form 1040) if you declare item-by-item deductions. Federal income tax is not deducted.

You can deduct taxes to Social Security, Medicare, and the Federal Unemployment Tax (FUTA) that you paid from your own funds as an employer. Taxes withheld by an employer from the wages of employees are briefly explained in Chapter 1. You can also deduct payments that you made as an employer to the state unemployment benefit fund or the state disability benefit fund.
You can deduct half the self-employment tax on line 15 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040).
You may deduct on Schedule C any tax imposed by local or state authorities on personal property used in business. You may also deduct registration fees for use of property in the state or local area.

You can deduct on Schedule C the real estate taxes you pay on your business property. Deductible real estate taxes are any local or foreign taxes, as well as state taxes, on real estate levied for the public good. The tax authority must levy these taxes equally at the same rate on all real estate under its jurisdiction and the proceeds must be used for the general purposes of the state or district.

If the service, cost, or use of the property is a deductible business expense, you may deduct the tax as part of that service or expense. If the property is a depreciable good, add the sales tax to the base for depreciation. For information on the property base, see Publication No. 551.
You can deduct in Schedule C all excise taxes that are normal and necessary expenses for the conduct of business.12 Excise taxes are briefly explained in Chapter 1.13

In general, your tax home is your usual place of work, regardless of where your family home is located. It includes the entire city or district in which your company is located. For more information, see Publication No. 463. Below is a brief description of the expenses that you can deduct.

If, after considering the places of business, your home cannot be identified as the main place of business, you will not be able to deduct the home office expenses. However, see Publication No. 587 for other ways to obtain the right to deduct the home office expenses.

As a rule, you must capitalize the cost of acquiring or producing real or tangible personal property used in your professional or commercial activity, such as buildings, equipment or furniture. However, if you choose to avail yourself of the de minimis benefit for tangible property, you may deduct the de minimis amounts paid for tangible property up to a maximum of $5,000 per item or invoice.
For more information on the choice and requirements for using the safe harbor rule for tangible assets, see the section “Regulations governing tangible assets”.

You may be eligible for the following expenses: Advertising. Banking fees. Donations to commercial organizations. Educational expenses. Disability expenses. Interview costs allowances. Licensing and regulatory fees. Moving equipment. Employment assistance services. Penalties and fines for late performance or non-performance of a contract. Repairs and maintenance of real or tangible personal property. Income recovery. Supplies and materials. Utilities.

Generally, you cannot deduct the following expenses as business expenses. Bribes and charges. Charity contributions. Demolition or damages expenses. Contributions to business, social, sports, dining, sports, aviation and hotel clubs. Entertainment expenses. Immovable or tangible personal property improvements. Improvements are amounts paid for improvements, restorations or works that adapt your property to a new or different use. Lobbying expenses. Penalties and fines that you pay to a public agency or authority because you broke the law. Personal, domestic and family expenses. Political contributions.

If someone owes you money that you cannot collect, you have bad debt. There are two types of bad debt – business and non-business. Business-related bad debt usually arises as a result of professional or commercial activities. You can deduct bad debt as an expense on your tax return.

Debt is considered closely related to your business if the primary motive for its creation was business activity. Goods and services for which customers have not paid are recorded in your books as receivables or bills of exchange. If you cannot collect any part of these receivables, then the uncollectible part is a bad debt. You can deduct bad debts on these accounts and bills of exchange only if the amount of the debt was included in your gross income, either for the year in which the deduction is made or for the previous year.

If you have declared a deduction for bad debt on your tax return and later recover (collect) the debt in whole or in part, you may have to include all or part of the amount received in your gross income. You must include in your income exactly as much as you actually deducted. However, you can exclude from your income the amount deducted that did not reduce your tax. Report the amount received as "Other Income" on the appropriate tax form or schedule. For more information, see the "Recoveries" section of Publication No. 525.
For more information on business bad debt, see section 166 of the Tax Code and its regulations.

If you use the accrual method of accounting, you usually report income when you earn it. You can get a bad debt deduction for uncollectible receivables if you have included the uncollectible amount in income.

If you are using cash accounting, you usually report income when you receive payment. You cannot deduct bad debt in respect of amounts owed to you that you have not received and cannot receive if you have never included those amounts in income.

Losses from company debts received in inheritance are classified in the same way as debt received when buying a company. The testator classifies any loss from debt as a business bad debt if the debt was closely related to the professional or commercial activity of the deceased when it became useless.

If your partnership breaks up and one of your former partners becomes insolvent, you may have to pay more than your proportionate share of the partnership’s debts. If this does happen, you can claim a bad debt deduction for the amount paid against the insolvent partner’s share.

You can deduct certain bad debt that becomes partially uncollectible during the tax year. Your tax deduction is limited to the amount you write off in your books during the year. You do not have to write off and deduct partially uncollectible debt annually. You can defer the write-off to a later year. However, you cannot deduct any part of the debt after the year in which it becomes completely uncollectible.

If the debt becomes completely useless in the current tax year, you can deduct the entire amount except for any amount deducted in the previous tax year when the debt was only partially useless. You do not have to actually write off the debt to show on your return that it is completely useless, but you should do so.

Local business transportation does not include expenses you incur during overnight trips from home. These expenses are deductible as business travel expenses and are explained in the section "Travel and meals". However, if you use your car during overnight trips away from home, use the rules in this section to calculate the deduction for car expenses. Generally, your tax home is your permanent place of work, regardless of where your family home is located. It includes the entire city or district u u where you work or do business.
For local transportation costs or overnight travel by car or truck, one of the following methods of calculation of costs can generally be used: standard rate per mile l Actual cost l

You can use the standard mileage rate to calculate your deductible expenses for operating your car, van, pickup or van for business purposes. For 2024, the standard rate for each mile travelled for commercial purposes is 67 cents.

If the property you acquire for business use is to be used for more than one year, you cannot generally deduct the entire cost as business expenses in the year of its acquisition. You must spread the expenses over more than 1 tax year and deduct part of it each year under Schedule C. This method of deducting the value of business property is called depreciation.

Instead, you deduct these amounts on line 21 of Schedule C. Improvements are amounts paid for improving your property, restoring your property, or doing work that adapts your property for a new or different use.
Use Form 4562, Depreciation and Amortization, if you are reporting any of the following: Depreciation of property put into service in the current tax year. Deduction under Section 179.

You cannot deduct insurance premiums under the following types of insurance. 1. Self-insurance reserve funds. You cannot deduct amounts credited to a reserve set up for self-insurance. This applies even if you cannot obtain insurance coverage for certain business risks. However, your actual losses may be deducted. For more information, see Publication No. 547. 2. Loss of earnings. You cannot deduct insurance premiums under a policy that pays for your lost earnings due to illness or disability. However, see item 8 in the previous list. 3. Certain types of life insurance and annuities. 1. Under contracts entered into before June 9, 1997, you cannot deduct insurance premiums under a life insurance policy under which you, an employee or any person having a financial interest in your business is insured if you are a direct or indirect beneficiary of the policy. You are included as a possible beneficiary of the policy if the policyholder is required to repay a loan received from you from the funds of the policy. A person has a financial interest in your business if they are the owner or co-owner of the business or have lent money to the business. 2. Under contracts entered into after June 8, 1997, you generally cannot deduct premiums under any life insurance policy, accumulation agreement or annuity agreement if you are a direct or indirect beneficiary. This prohibition applies regardless of who is covered by the policy. 4. Insurance to secure credit. If you take out insurance for your life or the life of another person having a financial interest in your business to obtain or protect credit, you cannot deduct insurance premiums as expenses of conducting business. You cannot deduct insurance premiums under a policy that pays for your lost earnings due to illness or disability.

Use Form 8962 and its separate instructions, as well as Publication No. 974, if an insurance plan created or deemed to have been created in your business was obtained through the health insurance market and you are claiming a tax deduction for insurance premiums.

For tax purposes, a foreigner is a person who is not a U.S. citizen. Aliens can be classified as temporary residents (non-resident aliens) and permanent residents (resident aliens). This publication will help you determine your status and give you the information you need to file a U.S. tax return. Resident aliens are generally taxed on their total income worldwide, just like U.S. citizens. Non-resident aliens are taxed only on income from sources in the United States and on certain income related to professional or commercial activities in the United States.

Partial suspension of the Income Tax Convention with the USSR in respect of Belarus. On December 17, 2024, the United States officially notified the Republic of Belarus of the partial suspension of the double taxation treaty with the USSR in respect of Belarus. The United States suspended Article 3(1)(g) of the Convention. The remaining articles of the treaty will remain in force. The suspension came into effect on December 17, 2024 and will expire on December 31, 2026, or earlier if the governments of both countries so decide. Partial suspension of the Income Tax Convention with Russia. On June 17, 2024, the United States officially notified the Russian Federation of the partial suspension of the agreement between the two countries. The United States suspended Article 1(4), Articles 5-21 and Article 23 of the Convention and the Protocol. The suspension came into effect on August 16, 2024, both for taxes originally withheld and for other taxes, and will remain in effect until the two governments agree to terminate it. Payments of income from sources in the United States made on or after August 16, 2024 must be taxed at the statutory rate of 30%. Taxpayers previously entitled to preferential taxation under the Russian-U.S. Income Tax Treaty. Spouse designated as a resident (permanent resident) of the United States. A check mark has been added to the Tax Status section of Forms 1040 and 1040-SR,

A non-resident alien (and some resident aliens) from a country with which the U.S. has a double taxation treaty may be eligible for certain benefits. Most treaties require that a non-resident alien be a resident of the treaty country to receive the benefit in the year it is requested. However, in the case of some students, trainees, teachers or researchers, some treaties require that a non-resident alien be a resident of the treaty country immediately prior to arriving in the U.S.

You can view the tables of the double taxation treaties at IRS.gov/TreatyTables. You can read the most recent U.S. double taxation treaties, protocols and exchange of tax information agreements (TIEA) and the accompanying Treasury Department technical explanations as they become available, as well as the Model Double Taxation Agreement at Home.Treasury.gov/Policy-Issues/Tax-Policy/International-Tax. Please note that the treaty and TIEA documents are posted on this site after signature and before ratification and entry into force. The full text of individual double taxation treaties can also be found at IRS.gov/Businesses/International-Businesses/United-States-Income-Tax-Treaties-A-to-Z. More information on double taxation treaties: IRS.gov/Individuals/International-Taxpayers/Tax-Treaties.

Non-Treaty Income is gross income that is taxed at a tax treaty rate not exceeding 15%. Non-Treaty Income is gross income that is not taxed at a tax treaty rate. To determine the tax on non-Treaty Income, calculate the tax at either a flat rate of 30% or a graduated rate, depending on whether the income is actually related to your professional or commercial activity in the United States.

The following is a summary of the benefits provided under the tax treaties for income from personal services, remittances, scholarships, grants and capital assets. The terms of the benefits vary by the specific tax treaty. For more information on the terms of a specific tax treaty, see the texts of most U.S. tax treaties on the same site.

Some double taxation treaties contain an “independent personal services” clause, which allows residents of the treaty country to exempt income earned as an independent contractor or self-employed person from U.S. taxation if such person is in the U.S. for a period not exceeding a certain number of days and if they do not have a fixed base regularly available to them in the U.S.12.

All treaties contain provisions for tax exemption on income earned by certain foreign governments. However, there is a difference in who is eligible for this benefit, depending on the specific treaty. Under many treaties, foreigners who are U.S. residents are not eligible for this benefit. Under most treaties, foreigners who are not citizens or subjects of the foreign state are not eligible for this benefit. Foreign governments should read the relevant treaty carefully to understand whether they are eligible for the benefits. Chapter 10 of this publication also contains information for foreign governments.
Foreign residents may claim benefits under tax treaties on avoidance of double taxation in the situations described below.

Foreign residents are usually not eligible for tax treaty benefits because most tax treaties contain an exclusion clause that retains the right of the U.S. to tax its nationals and residents as if the tax treaty had not come into force. However, many tax treaties have exceptions to the clause that may allow a foreign resident to continue to claim benefits under the treaty. Some exceptions to such a clause apply to all foreign residents (for example, under the U.S.-People's Republic of China treaty); others apply only to foreign residents who are not lawful permanent residents of the U.S. (green card holders). In certain cases, you do not need to report income on Form 1040 or 1040-SR because, under the treaty, that income will be exempt from U.S. tax. However, if the income was reported as taxable income on Form W-2, Form 1042-S, Form 1099 or other information return, you should report it on the appropriate line of Form 1040 or 1040-SR (for example, line 1a, amounts specified in column 1 of Form W-2). Enter the amount claimed for the treaty benefits in Schedule 1 (Form 1040), line 8z. Enter "Exempt income" in parentheses, the name of the treaty country and the treaty article providing for the exemption. For income that is treaty-taxed at a reduced rate but not exempt, attach the following:

Generally, you must be a non-resident alien, student, apprentice, intern, teacher, professor or researcher, to qualify for a treaty tax exemption on remittances from abroad for U.S. education and maintenance, scholarships, grants and research grants, and wages or other remuneration for personal services. Once you become a resident alien, you generally no longer qualify for a treaty tax exemption on that income. However, if you entered the U.S. as a non-resident alien, but are now a resident alien for U.S. taxation purposes, the treaty tax exemption will continue to apply if a tax treaty clause (described above) provides an exception for it, and you otherwise meet the requirements for the treaty tax exemption (including any time limits for applying the treaty tax exemption as described below).

In some cases, you do not need to report income on Form 1040 or 1040-SR because the income is not taxed in the U.S. under the treaty. However, if the income was reported as taxable income on Form W-2, Form 1042-S, Form 1099, or other disclosure, you should report it on the appropriate line of Form 1040 or 1040-SR (for example, line 1a, amounts listed in Form W-2, column 1). Enter the amount claimed under the treaty in Schedule 1 (Form 1040), line 8z. Enter "Exempt income" in parentheses, the name of the treaty country, and the treaty article that provides for the exemption.

If you claim an agreement benefit that overrides or modifies any provision of the Tax Code and your tax is or may be reduced as a result of the claim, you must attach a properly completed Form 8833 to your tax return. See the "Exceptions" section below for situations where you are not required to file Form 8833.

You are not required to file Form 8833 in any of the following situations. 1. You claim a tax reduction under the agreement on interest, dividends, rent, royalties or other fixed or determined annual or recurring income normally taxed at the 30% rate. 2. You claim that the agreement reduces or alters the taxation of income from personal dependent services, pensions, annuities, social security and other government pensions, or income from performers, athletes, students, interns or teachers. This includes taxable scholarships and scholarship grants. 3. You claim a tax reduction or alteration under an international social security treaty or diplomatic or consular treaty. 4. You are a partner in a partnership or beneficiary of an inheritance or trust, and the partnership, inheritance or trust provides the required information in its return. 5. Payments or items of income that are otherwise required to be disclosed are not more than $10,000. 6. You claim benefits under the agreement for amounts that... 1. are reported to you on Form 1042-S (referring to Form 5472 disclosure returns filed by U.S. corporations that are 25% owned by a foreign person), or 2. are received by you... 1. as a related party from a reporting corporation, or 2. as a beneficial owner who is a direct owner of an account with a U.S. financial institution or a qualified intermediary, or a direct partner, beneficiary or owner of a retaining foreign corporation.

Employees of international organizations may exempt their wages from income tax pursuant to a provision, if any, in an international agreement establishing an international organization, or by meeting the requirements for an exemption from U.S. income tax for such wages pursuant to U.S. tax law.

You should first review the tax exemption provisions under the Vienna Conventions or a bilateral consular treaty, if any, to determine whether your salary is eligible for U.S. income tax exemption under those provisions. Generally, you are not eligible for income tax exemption under the Vienna Conventions or a bilateral consular treaty if you are a U.S. citizen or resident alien. For more information about the Vienna Conventions and bilateral consular treaties, please contact the Office of Foreign Missions of the State Department at OFMAssistants@state.gov.

If you are not eligible for tax exemption under the Vienna Conventions or bilateral consular conventions, but are a citizen of a country that has a double taxation agreement with the United States, you should consult that agreement to see if it has a provision that exempts your salary from U.S. income tax. If you are a U.S. citizen or a resident alien working in the United States for a foreign government, your salary is usually not exempt from tax. For more information, see the section "Wages and Pensions Paid by a Foreign Government" in Publication No. 901.

Employees of foreign governments who do not qualify for tax exemption under any of the Vienna Conventions, a bilateral consular treaty or a double taxation agreement may be exempted from U.S. income tax if they meet the following requirements for exemption from taxation of such wages under U.S. tax law. The tax exemption under U.S. tax law applies only to current employees of foreign governments, not to former employees.

If the international organization agreement for which you work does not contain a tax exemption provision and you are not a U.S. citizen (or if you are a U.S. citizen but also a citizen of the Republic of the Philippines), you may be eligible for tax exemption under U.S. law. However, see the subsection "Aliens with Retained Immigration Status (Legal Permanent Resident)" below for a special rule that may affect your eligibility for this exemption.

If you sign a waiver under Section 247(b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (Form I-508) to retain your legal permanent resident status (“green card”), you are no longer eligible for tax exemption under U.S. tax laws from the date of the waiver.
If you are a foreigner, fall under category (1) or (2) above, and you have filed a request for denial under section 247(b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act, you must obtain a permit to leave.

International students, interns, and exchange visitors, including their spouses and children, who enter the United States only on F-1, F-2, H-3, H-4, J-1, J-2, or Q visas and who do not receive income from U.S. sources while in the United States on these visas, other than... benefits to cover expenses related to study or internship in the United States, such as travel, maintenance, and tuition costs; the cost of any services, meals, and accommodation associated with such study or tuition; income from employment authorized by the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS); or interest income on deposits that are not directly related to professional or commercial activities in the United States. See the subsection "Interest Income" in Chapter 3.

International students, including their spouses and children, who enter the United States only on an M-1 or M-2 visa and who do not earn income from sources in the United States while in the United States on these visas, except for... income from employment authorized by the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS), or interest income on deposits that are not directly related to professional or commercial activities in the United States.

Certain other non-resident aliens who have not earned taxable income in the tax year prior to the date of departure or in the previous tax year. If the IRS has reason to believe that the alien has earned taxable income and that the collection of income tax may be impeded by departure, the IRS may require the alien to obtain a leave permit. This category includes the following groups. 1. Foreign military trainees who enter the United States for education under the auspices of the Department of Defense and leave the United States on official military assignments; 2. Foreign business visitors on a B-1 visa, or on B-1 and B-2 visas, who do not stay in the United States or U.S.-administered territories for more than 90 days in the tax year; 3. Foreign tourist visitors on a B-2 visa; 4. Foreigners transiting through the United States or U.S.-administered territories on a "C-1 visa" or under a contract, such as a sale and purchase agreement, between a transportation company and the Attorney General; and 5. Foreigners who enter the United States on a border crossing ID or who do not require a passport, visa or ID to cross the border if they...
Foreigners from Canada or Mexico who frequently travel from these countries to the United States to work and whose wages are subject to U.S. withholding tax.

1. Your passport and foreigner registration card or visa. 2. Copies of your U.S. tax returns filed for the last 2 years. If you have been in the United States for less than 2 years, bring the tax returns you filed for that period. 3. Income tax receipts for those returns. 4. Receipts, bank records, cancelled cheques and other documents proving your withholdings, business expenses and dependents listed in your income. 5. A statement from each employer showing the wages paid and taxes withheld from January 1 of the current year to the date of departure if you were an employed person. If you were self-employed, you must provide a statement of income and expenses up to the date you plan to leave. 6. Confirmation of any estimated tax payments for the past and current year. 7. Documents proving any profit or loss from the sale of personal and/or real property, including fixed assets and goods. 8. Documents relating to scholarships or grants, including... 1. documentary proof of the founder, source and purpose of the grant. 2. copies of the grant application and its approval. 3. statement of the amount paid and your purposes and obligations under the grant. 4. list of all previous grants. 9. documents proving your eligibility for claimed special tax benefits. 10. document proving the date of your departure.

Foreigners in any of these categories who have not filed an income tax return or paid income tax for any tax year must file a tax return and pay income tax before they are issued a leave permit on Form 2063.

If you need to get a leave and you are not eligible to file Form 2063, you must file Form 1040-C. Normally, all income earned or reasonably expected to be earned during the tax year up to and including the date of departure must be reported on Form 1040-C and tax must be paid on it. When you pay any tax listed as payable on Form 1040-C and you file all returns and pay all taxes due for previous years, you are granted a leave. However, the IRS may allow you to provide a bond to guarantee payment in place of tax payment for certain years. See the "Security Bond" section below.

If you provide information to the satisfaction of the IRS that you intend to return to the United States and that your departure will not jeopardize the collection of income tax, you may be granted a leave to leave by completing Form 1040-C without having to pay the tax listed on it. However, you must file all tax returns that have not yet been duly filed and pay all income tax due on those returns.

You must pay all taxes listed as due on Form 1040-C at the time of filing, unless a deposit is provided or the IRS is satisfied that your departure does not prevent the collection of income tax. You must also pay any past tax debts. If the tax calculation on Form 1040-C results in an overpayment, no tax is charged on the return. However, the IRS cannot provide a refund at the time of departure. If you are entitled to a refund, you must file Form 1040-NR at the end of the tax year.

You are usually required to pay the tax listed as due on Form 1040-C when you file it. However, if you are paying all your taxes for previous years, you may provide a bond to secure payment instead of paying the income tax listed as due on Form 1040-C or on the previous year's tax return, provided that the tax return period has not expired.

If an income tax return is required by law, it must be filed even if a Form 1040-C has already been filed. Chapters 5 and 7 discuss the procedure for filing an annual U.S. income tax return. Tax paid using Form 1040-C must be credited to your tax liability for the entire tax year on your annual U.S. income tax return.

Go to IRS.gov/Account for secure access to your federal tax account information. View amounts due and breakdowns by tax year. View payment agreement details or apply for a new payment plan. Make a payment, view 5-year payment history and any upcoming or scheduled payments. Get online access to tax documents, including key information from your latest return and statements. View electronic copies of some IRS notifications. Approve or reject an authorization request submitted by a tax professional. Verify your address or choose how you want to receive notifications.

With an online account, you can access a variety of information that will help you through the filing process. You can get a statement, view your last filed tax return and update your adjusted gross income.

The safest and easiest way to get your tax refund is to file online and choose a direct deposit, which provides a secure electronic transfer of your return directly to your financial account. Direct deposit also eliminates the possibility that your check may be lost, stolen, destroyed or returned to the IRS. Eight out of ten taxpayers use the direct deposit method to receive their refund. If you do not have a bank account, go to IRS.gov/DirectDeposit for more information on where to find a bank or credit union that can open an online account for you.

For returns claiming an Earned Income Credit (EIC) or Additional Child Tax Credit (ACTC), the IRS may not issue a refund until mid-February. This deadline applies to the entire refund of overpaid taxes, not just the part related to these credits.

Federal tax payments must be made to the IRS in U.S. dollars. Digital assets are not accepted. Go to IRS.gov/Payments for more information on how to make a payment using one of the following options. IRS Direct : Pay your individual tax bill or quarterly assessment tax at no additional charge, directly from your checking or savings account. Debit card, credit card or e-wallet : Choose an approved payment system for payments via the Internet or by phone. Electronic withdrawal : Available only when filing federal taxes using tax preparation software or through a tax professional. Electronic Federal Tax Payment : Best for business. Registration required. Check or money order : Send your payment by mail to the address provided in the notification or instructions. Cash : You can pay your taxes in cash at a participating retail store. Same-day delivery : You may be able to make a transfer on the same day from your financial institution. Contact your financial institution to learn about the availability, cost and time of the service.

Go to IRS.gov/Payments for more information on payment options. Apply for an online payment agreement (IRS.gov/OPA) to meet your tax obligations in monthly payments if you are unable to pay your taxes in full today.

If you still need help, TAC provides tax assistance when a tax issue cannot be resolved online or over the phone. All TACs now offer pre-scheduled services, so you will know in advance that you can get the service you need without a long wait. Before you visit, go to IRS.gov/TACLocator to find your nearest TAC and find out about its opening hours, available services and how to schedule a meeting.

The Taxpayer Advice Service (TAS) is an independent organization within the IRS that helps taxpayers solve problems after they contact the IRS, offers administrative and legislative advice to prevent or resolve problems, and protects taxpayer rights. We strive to ensure that every taxpayer is treated fairly and that you know and understand your rights under the Taxpayer Bill of Rights.
If you are a sole proprietorship, partnership or S-Corporation, you can view your tax information and more by opening a company tax account. For more information, visit IRS.gov/BusinessAccount.

I am temporarily in the United States for the purpose of studying or training at [enter the name of the university or other recognized educational institution at which you are studying]; or I am temporarily in the United States as a recipient of a grant, benefit or award from [enter the name of the non-profit organization or government agency granting the grant, benefit or award]. 3. This compensation is exempt from federal income tax withholding under a tax treaty between the U.S. and [enter the name of the country] in an amount not exceeding $5,000 (US$10,000 if you are a participant in a government-sponsored educational program of up to 1 year) for any tax year. 4. I have arrived in the United States of America [enter the date of your last arrival in the United States prior to the start of your studies at a U.S. educational institution]. The tax exemption of $5,000 is available only for compensation paid within 5 tax years from the tax year that includes the date of my arrival.

1. I was a resident of Egypt at the time of my arrival in the United States. I am not a U.S. citizen. I have not been granted the legal privilege of permanent residence in the United States as an immigrant. 2. I am temporarily in the United States for the purpose of studying at [insert name of the university or other recognized educational institution at which you are studying]. 3. I will receive compensation for personal services rendered in the United States. This compensation is exempt from federal income tax under the U.S.-Egyptian tax treaty in an amount not exceeding $3,000 ($10,000 if you are a participant in a government-sponsored educational program of up to 1 year) for any tax year.

1. I was a resident of France at the time of my arrival in the United States. I am not a U.S. citizen. I was not legally granted the privilege of permanent residence in the United States as an immigrant. 2. I am temporarily in the United States for the purpose of studying at [insert name of accredited university, college, school or other educational institution]. 3. I will receive compensation for personal services rendered in the United States. This compensation is exempt from federal income tax withholding under the U.S.-France tax treaty in an amount not exceeding US$5,000 in any tax year. I have not previously claimed an exemption from income tax under this treaty in respect of income earned as a teacher, researcher or student prior to the date of my arrival in the United States. 4. I will remain in the United States only for such a period of time as may be reasonably or normally necessary for the purpose of this visit. 5.
