I have arrived in the United States on [insert date of your last arrival in the United States prior to the commencement of studying at a U.S. educational institution]. The exemption under this treatyi is available only for compensation payable within 5 tax years.

1. I was a resident of Germany at the time of my arrival in the United States. I am not a U.S. citizen. I have not been legally granted the privilege of permanent residence in the United States as an immigrant. 2. I am temporarily in the United States as a student or intern for the purpose of full-time study or training at the following institution: [insert name of accredited university, college, school or other educational institution]; or I am temporarily in the United States as a recipient of a grant, benefit or award from [insert name of non-profit organization or government agency granting the grant, benefit or award]. 3. I will receive compensation for employment services performed in the United States of America. This compensation is exempt from federal income tax in any tax year, provided that such services are provided to supplement funds available for my salary, education or training. 4. I have arrived in the United States on [insert date of your last arrival in the United States prior to the start of my studies at a U.S. institution].

1. I was a resident of Iceland at the time of my arrival in the United States. I am not a U.S. citizen. I have not been legally granted the privilege of permanent residence in the United States as an immigrant. 2. I am temporarily in the United States for the purpose of studying at [insert name of the university or other recognized educational institution at which you are studying]; or I am temporarily in the United States for training, education or research as a recipient of a grant, benefit or award from [insert name of the non-profit organization or government agency granting the grant, benefit or award].

The treaty with the former Union of Soviet Socialist Republics remains in effect for the following countries: Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Kyrgyzstan, Moldova, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan. 1. I am a resident of [insert country name]. I am not a U.S. citizen. 2. I have received an invitation from a U.S. government agency or institution, an educational or research institution in the U.S. to come to the U.S. for the purpose of teaching, conducting research or attending scientific, technical or professional conferences in [insert name of government agency or institution, educational or scientific institution, or professional conference sponsoring organization], which is a government agency or institution, educational or research institution, or professional conference sponsoring organization. I will receive compensation for my teaching, research or conference participation. 3. Teaching, research or conference participation compensation received for the entire tax year (or for the period from to ) under that treaty is eligible for exemption from federal tax withholding under a tax treaty between the U.S. and the former Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. I have not previously claimed an income tax exemption under that treaty in respect of income earned as a teacher, researcher, conference participant or student prior to the date of my arrival in the U.S. 4. Any research I conduct will not be for the benefit of a U.S. individual or U.S. business enterprise or foreign trade organization [insert country name], except where the research is conducted under intergovernmental cooperation agreements. 5. I arrived in the U.S. [insert date of your last arrival in the United States prior to the commencement of the teaching or research activity for which exemption is requested].

1. I am a resident of Germany. I am not a U.S. citizen. I have not been granted the privilege of legal permanent residence in the United States as an immigrant. 2. I am a professor or lecturer in the United States for the purpose of further training, teaching or conducting research at [insert name of accredited university, college, school or other educational institution, or government research institution or other institution engaged in public-benefit research]. I will receive compensation for my teaching, research or teaching activities. 3. Compensation received during the entire tax year (or between) for these activities qualifies for exemption from federal tax withholding under the U.S.-German tax treaty. I have not previously claimed an exemption from income tax under this treaty in respect of income earned as a student, apprentice or trainee during the immediately preceding period. (However, if after the period during which the foreigner claimed benefits as a student, apprentice or intern, he returns to Germany and renews his residence and physical presence before returning to the U.S. as a lecturer or researcher, he may claim benefits under this treaty.) 4. Any research I conduct will be in the public interest and not for the personal benefit of a particular person or persons. 5. I arrived in the United States of America [insert date of your last arrival in the United States prior to the commencement of the services for which exemption is requested]. The treaty exemption is available only for compensation paid within 2 years from the date of the first time I entered the United States of America.

You are a legal permanent resident of the United States at any time during the 2024 calendar year. (However, see the "Aliens with Dual Status" section below.) This is also called the "Green Card" test. You are a legal permanent resident of the United States at any time if you have been granted the privilege, under U.S. immigration law, to reside in the United States as an immigrant.

If you file by mail, you must send the requested tax return (or its foreign equivalent) by registered mail and keep a copy and proof of receipt of the letter. Until you have proof that your letter has been received, you remain a resident alien for tax purposes, even if USCIS does not recognize the validity of your green card because it is more than 10 years old or because you have been away from the United States for a certain period of time.

A foreign government-associated individual is an individual (or an immediate relative) who is temporarily in the United States... as a full-time employee of an international organization, by virtue of his or her diplomatic status or on a visa (other than a visa granting the right to lawful permanent residence) that, as defined by the Department of the Treasury, is issued to persons in permanent diplomatic or consular status.

A foreign employer includes an office or place of business of a U.S. organization in a foreign state or territory administered by the U.S. If you are eligible to exclude days of presence in the U.S. as a teacher or intern, you must file a fully completed Form 8843 with the IRS. See the "Form 8843" subsection below.

Even if you meet the long-term residence criteria, you may be considered a non-resident alien if... you are in the United States for less than 183 days per year, your tax home is in a foreign state for a year, and you have a closer connection per year with one foreign state where your tax home is located than with the United States (unless you have a closer connection with two foreign states, as discussed below).

You can prove that you have a closer connection to two foreign states (but not more than two) if you meet all of the following conditions. You have a tax home from the first day of the year in one foreign state. During the year you have changed your tax home to a second foreign state. Your tax home has continued to remain in the second foreign state until the end of the year. You have had a closer connection to each foreign state than to the United States for the period that your tax home has continued to be in that foreign state. You have been taxable as a resident under the tax laws of one of the foreign states for the entire year or have been taxable as a resident in both foreign states for the period that your tax home has been in each foreign state.

A tax home is the common territory of your main place of business, work or service, regardless of where you live. A tax home is the place where you work permanently or indefinitely as an employee or a sole trader. If you do not have a permanent or main place of work because of the nature of your activity, then your tax home is the place where you regularly live.

It does not matter whether your permanent residence is a house, an apartment or a furnished room. It also does not matter whether you rent it or own it. It is important, however, that your home is available permanently and at all times, and not only for a short stay.

If you are a dual resident taxpayer, you may still qualify for benefits under a double taxation agreement. A dual resident taxpayer is a taxpayer who is a resident of the United States and another country under the tax laws of each of those countries. A double taxation agreement between the two countries must contain a provision to resolve conflicting claims of residence (the "tie-break" rule).

If you are a dual resident taxpayer claiming a double taxation treaty benefit, you must file a return using Form 1040-NR with an annex of Form 8833 and calculate your tax as a non-resident alien. A dual resident taxpayer may also be eligible for assistance from a U.S. tax authority. See Tax Procedure 2015-40, 2015-35 I.R.B. 236, available at IRS.gov/irb/2015-35_IRB#RP-2015-40 or later. For more information on reporting treaty benefits, see "How to report treaty benefits claimed?" in Chapter 9.
You can be both a non-resident alien and a resident alien in the same tax year. This usually happens in the year you enter or leave the United States.

You cannot file Form 1040 or 1040-SR or this application until you meet the 2025 substantial presence test. If you do not pass the 2025 test as of April 15, 2025, you may request an extension of time to file your 2024 Form 1040 or 1040-SR for a reasonable period after you become eligible for long-term residence. To request an extension of time to file until October 15, 2025, use Form 4868. You can file the form on paper or use one of the electronic filing options described in the Form 4868 instructions. Given this extension, you must pay your 2024 tax arrears as if you were a non-resident alien all year. To calculate your tax, you can use Form 1040-NR. Enter the tax amount on Form 4868. If you fail to pay your tax arrears, you will be charged interest on any tax not paid by the due date, and you may be subject to a late payment penalty. Once you have made your choice of the first year, you cannot change it without the approval of the IRS. If you fail to follow the procedures described here for choosing the first year, you will be considered a non-resident alien for the entire year 2024. However, this rule does not work if you have clear and convincing evidence that you have taken reasonable steps to learn about the filing procedures and the important steps to comply with those procedures.

You usually make this choice when you file a joint tax return. However, you can also make the choice by filing a Form 1040-X, Amended Individual Tax Return of a U.S. Citizen. Attach Form 1040 or 1040-SR and enter “Amended” at the top of the amended tax return. If you choose an amended tax return, you and your spouse must also amend any tax returns that you may have filed after the selected year.

You can only use this date if your tax address was in another country before the end of 2024 and you had a closer connection with that foreign country. See the subsection "Closer connection with a foreign state" presented above.

If you are married at the end of the tax year and one spouse is a U.S. citizen or a resident alien and the other spouse is a non-resident alien, you have the option of designating the non-resident spouse as a resident for the purposes of income taxation for the entire tax year. Neither you nor your spouse can request to waive your status as a U.S. resident under any tax treaty.

The decision on whether to have foreign resident status is suspended for any tax year (after the tax year you have chosen) if neither spouse is a U.S. citizen or a resident foreigner at any time during the tax year.

Once you have elected resident status, it applies to all subsequent years, unless it is suspended (as explained in "Suspension of Electing Status") or terminated by one of the following methods. If the election has ceased to be valid by one of the following methods, neither spouse can make the election in any subsequent tax year. 1. Cancellation. Either spouse may cancel the election for any tax year provided that he or she completes the cancellation before the due date for filing the tax return for that tax year. The spouse who cancels the election must attach a signed statement that the election is cancelled. The application must include the name, address and identification number (TIN) of each spouse. (If one spouse dies, provide the name and address of the person who cancels the election in place of the deceased spouse.) The application must also include a list of all states, foreign countries and territories where joint property laws are in effect and where one spouse resides or where property is located that generates income for either spouse. File the application as follows. 1. If the cancelling spouse must file a tax return, attach the application to the return for the first year of the cancellation. 2. If the cancelling spouse does not have to file a tax return but does (for example, to claim a refund), attach the application to the tax return. 3. If the cancelling spouse does not have to file a tax return and does not file a tax return even for a refund, send the application to the same IRS location where you last filed your joint tax return. 2. Death. The death of one spouse terminates the election, beginning with the date of the death of the spouse.

If you are a resident alien, you must report all interest, dividends, wages or other payments for services, income from leasing property or royalties, and other types of income on your U.S. tax return. You must report these amounts from sources in the U.S. and abroad.

Non-resident aliens are taxed only on their income from United States sources and on certain income related to the pursuit of a professional or business activity in the United States (see chapter 4). The general rules for determining income from U.S. sources that apply to most non-resident aliens are shown in Table 2-1. The following discussions cover the general rules as well as exceptions to these rules. Not all items of income from U.S. sources are taxed. See chapter 3.

Real property is land and buildings, and generally everything that is built on, grows on or is attached to land.1 Gross income from United States sources includes the increase, profit and income from the sale or other disposition of real property located in the United States.2

Income from the sale of the products of any farm, mine, oil or gas well, other natural resource, or timber located in the United States and sold in a foreign state, or located in a foreign state and sold in the United States, is partly income from U.S. sources.

Personal property is property such as machinery, equipment, or furniture that is not real property. Profits or losses from the sale or exchange of personal property are usually derived from sources in the United States if your tax home is in the United States. If your tax home is not in the United States, the profits or losses are usually derived from sources outside the United States.

Tax house is the common territory of your main place of business, work or service, regardless of where you live. Tax house is the place where you work permanently or indefinitely as an employee or sole trader. If you do not have a permanent or main place of work because of the nature of your activity, then your tax house is the place where you regularly reside. If you do not fit into either of these categories, you are considered a person moving from place to place and your tax house is the place where you work.

Inventory is personal property used in trade or primarily intended for sale to buyers in the course of ordinary professional or business activities. Income from the sale of inventory you acquire is deemed to be received at the place of sale of the property. Usually, this is the place where ownership of the property passes to the buyer. For example, income from the sale of inventory in the United States is income from a source in the United States, whether you acquired it in the United States or elsewhere. Income from the sale of inventory that you made in the United States and sold outside the United States (or vice versa) is income from a source in the United States. These rules apply even if your tax home is not in the United States.

To determine the source of income from the sale of depreciable personal property, you must first calculate the portion of the income that does not exceed the total amount of depreciation adjustments on the property. You allocate that portion of the gains among U.S. sources based on the ratio of U.S. depreciation adjustments to the total amount of depreciation adjustments. The remainder of the gains is considered to have been received from sources outside the U.S. In this case, “U.S. depreciation adjustments” are depreciation adjustments to the property base that are allowed in calculating taxable income from U.S. sources. However, if the property is used predominantly in the U.S. during a tax year, all depreciation deductions allowed for that year are treated as U.S. depreciation adjustments. But there are some exceptions for certain vehicles, communications equipment and other property used internationally. Gains from the sale of depreciable property that exceed the total amount of depreciation adjustments on the property are treated as if the property were inventory, as discussed above. Loss is treated in the same way as depreciation deductions. However, if the property was used predominantly in the U.S., all loss reduces income from the U.S. source. The property base usually means the cost (money plus the fair market value of other property or services) of the property you acquired. Depreciation is the amount deducted to recover the cost or other base of an asset used in a professional or commercial activity. The amount you can deduct depends on the value of the property, when you began using the property, and whether you have a depreciation adjustment on the property.

Intangible property includes patents, copyrights, secret processes or formulas, goodwill, trademarks, trade names and other similar property. Profits from the sale of amortising or depreciating intangible property within the limits of previously allowed depreciation or wear deductions are treated in the same way as the original deductions. This rule is similar to the source rule for profits from the sale of amortising property. See the subsection "Depreciable property" above for details on how to apply this rule. Profits exceeding depreciation deductions are considered to be sourced in the country where the property is used if the income from the sale depends on the productivity, use or disposal of the property.

Notwithstanding any of the foregoing rules, if your tax home is not in the United States, but you have an office or other permanent place of business in the United States, income from any sale of personal property (including stock) relating to that office or place of business is considered income from a U.S. source. However, this rule does not apply to the sale of inventory for use, disposal or consumption outside the U.S. if your office or other permanent place of business outside the U.S. was materially involved in the sale.

Interest income from a U.S. source does not include the following items. 1. Interest paid by a foreign resident or a domestic corporation on bonds issued before August 10, 2010, if, in the three-year period ending at the end of the payer's tax year preceding the payment of the interest, at least 80% (0.80) of the total gross income... 1. came from sources outside the U.S. and 2. is related to the active pursuit of a profession or business by a person or entity in another country or territory administered by the U.S. However, the interest will be considered as interest income from a U.S. source if one of the following conditions applies. 1.

In most cases, dividend income from domestic corporations is income from U.S. sources. Dividend income from foreign corporations is usually income from a foreign source. An exception to the second rule is discussed later. A substitute payment of dividends to a transferor of securities under a securities lending or repurchase transaction is accounted for in the same way as a distribution on the transferred security.

The payment of the equivalent of dividends includes any gross amount that refers to dividends from a U.S. source and that is used to calculate any net amount transferred to or from the taxpayer under the contract if the taxpayer is the party entitled to receive payments under the contract. As a result, the taxpayer may be considered to have received a payment equivalent to dividends even if the taxpayer makes a net payment or pays no amount as the net amount is zero.

All wages and any other remuneration for services performed in the United States are deemed to be received from U.S. sources. The only exceptions to this rule are discussed in the "Employees of Foreign Persons, Organizations or Offices" subsection below, and in the "Crew Members" subsection above. If you are an employee and receive remuneration for work or personal services performed both in the United States and abroad, special rules apply to the determination of the source of remuneration.

Some companies sell products under a multi-level marketing scheme, in which a top-level distributor who has sponsored a lower-level distributor is entitled to payments from the company based on certain actions of that lower-level distributor. Typically, depending on the facts, payments from such multi-level marketing companies to independent (non-employed) distributors (top-level distributors) based on the sales or purchases of the persons they have sponsored (lower-level distributors) constitute income for the performance of personal services in the recruitment, training and support of lower-level distributors. The source of such income is usually dependent on the location of the services provided by the top-level distributor and may, depending on the facts, be considered as a multi-year remuneration, the source of income being determined over the period to which such remuneration relates.

The source of multi-year remuneration is usually determined on a time-based basis over the period to which the remuneration relates. Multi-year remuneration is remuneration that is included in your income in one tax year but relates to a period that includes 2 or more tax years. You determine the period to which the remuneration relates based on the facts and circumstances of your case. For example, the amount of remuneration that relates to a period of time that includes several calendar years relates to the entire multi-year period. The amount of remuneration that is considered to have been received from U.S. sources is determined by multiplying the total amount of remuneration for the multi-year period by a fraction. The numerator of the fraction is the number of days (or a unit of time less than a day, if applicable) that you have performed U.S. employment or personal services in connection with the project. The denominator of the fraction is the total number of days (or a unit of time less than one day, if applicable) that you have worked or provided personal services in connection with the project.

The above additional benefits, except for tax reimbursement and hazardous or hard work allowances, are calculated based on the main place of work. The main place of work is usually the place where you spend most of your working time. This can be your office, factory, store, store or other place. If there is no such place where you spend most of your working time, then your main place of work is the place where your work is concentrated, i.e. where you attend work or are required to “do” your work. If you have several workplaces at the same time, the location of your main place of work depends on the facts of each case. The most important factors to consider are … the total time you spend in each place, the amount of work you do in each place, and how much money you earn in each place.

The source of educational allowance for the educational expenses of your dependants is determined by the location of your main place of employment. The educational allowance includes only the following expenses for primary or secondary schooling: tuition fees, fees, academic tutoring, services for students with special needs, books, supplies and other equipment, room and boarding and uniforms required or provided by the school in connection with enrolment or attendance, and the cost of the schooling of your dependents.
The source of the tax refund is the jurisdiction that assessed the tax for which you are getting a refund.

The source of relocation reimbursement is usually determined by the location of your new primary workplace. However, the source is determined by the location of your former primary workplace if you provide sufficient evidence that such a determination of source is more appropriate in the facts and circumstances of your case. Sufficient evidence usually requires an agreement between you and your employer or a written statement of company policy that was drawn up prior to the relocation and made or established to encourage you or other employees to relocate to another country. The written statement or agreement must state that your employer will reimburse you for the relocation costs you incur to return to your former primary workplace, whether you continue to work for your employer after returning to that place. u It may contain certain conditions that determine the eligibility for reimbursement, provided that those conditions set clear standards that can only be met before or as a result of the completion of your relocation to your former primary workplace.

If you are an employee, you may determine the source of your compensation on an alternative basis if you prove to the IRS that, in the facts and circumstances of your case, the alternative basis determines the source of your compensation more accurately than the time or geographic basis. If you use an alternative basis, you must keep documentation (including for verification) that supports why the alternative basis determines the source of your compensation more accurately. Also, if the total amount of compensation from all sources is $250,000 or more, answer “Yes” to both questions on line K of Schedule OI (Form 1040-NR) and attach a written statement to your tax return that includes the following: 1. Your name and Social Security Number (SSN) (entered at the top of the return). 2. The specific remuneration income or specific additional benefit for which you use the alternative basis. 3. For each item in (2), the alternative source distribution base used. 4. For each item in (2), a calculation showing how the alternative distribution was calculated. 5. A comparison of the dollar amount of U.S. compensation and foreign compensation received on both the alternative and the time or geographic basis described above.

This applies whether the surface vessel or aircraft is owned, leased or leased. The term “surface vessel or aircraft” includes any container used in connection with the surface vessel or aircraft. All income from transportation that begins or ends in the United States is treated as income from U.S. sources.

If you receive a pension from a national fund for services rendered both in the United States and abroad, a portion of your pension payments comes from U.S. sources. This portion is the amount related to the pension plan income and the employer contributions made for services rendered in the United States. This rule applies regardless of whether payments are made under a qualifying or non-qualifying stock reward plan, retirement plan, profit-sharing plan or annuity (whether or not it is a contributory one). If you have worked as a U.S. employee, you may receive a distribution from the U.S. government under a plan, such as the Public Service Pension System, that is considered a qualifying pension plan. Your income from a U.S. source is the taxable amount of payments that relate to your total U.S. government base salary, excluding tax-free fees for services rendered outside the U.S. u2.

Your income from a U.S. source includes real estate income and royalties received during the tax year from property located in the U.S. or from any interest in such property. Income from a U.S. source also includes real estate income or royalties for the use or privilege of use of intangible property in the U.S., such as patents, copyrights, secret processes and formulas, goodwill, trademarks, franchises and similar property12.
In these cases, you and your spouse must declare the joint income as described below.

The earned income of the spouse(s), except for the income from professional or commercial activities and the partner ' s distributional share in the partnership ' s income, is treated as the income of the spouse whose services have generated the income, and that spouse must declare such income in his/her separate tax return.

Income from professional or commercial activities other than the distributable share of the partner in the income of the partnership is considered as income of the spouse(s) engaged in professional or commercial activities, who must declare such income in his/her separate tax return.
The partner’s distributive share in the company’s income (or loss) is treated as the partner’s income (or loss).

Income from one spouse's separate property (which is not earned income, income from professional or commercial activities or income from a distributable share in a partnership) is considered to be that spouse's income. u That spouse must declare such income in his/her separate tax return. u Use the relevant law on joint property to determine what is separate property. u

Resident and non-resident aliens are allowed to have an exclusion from gross income if they meet certain conditions. An exclusion from gross income is generally income that you receive but that is not included in your U.S. income and is not taxed in the U.S. This chapter discusses some of the most common exclusions allowed to resident and non-resident aliens.

Interest income not related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States is excluded from income if it relates to... deposits (including certificates of deposit) in financial institutions; deposits or withdrawal accounts in mutual savings banks, cooperative banks, credit unions, local building and credit associations and other savings institutions registered and regulated as savings and credit or similar associations under federal or state law (if interest paid or credited is deductible by the association); and amounts retained by an insurance company pursuant to an agreement to pay interest thereon.11

Interest on bonds issued by a state or political entity, the District of Columbia or a territory administered by the United States is generally not included in income; however, interest on certain private-sector bonds, arbitration bonds and some unregistered bonds are included in income.

Interest not subject to taxation does not include contingent interest. contingent interest is any of the following: 1. interest determined by reference to... any income, sales or other cash flows of the debtor or a related person; income or profits of the debtor or a related person; any change in the value of any property of the debtor or a related person; or any dividends, partnership payments or similar payments made by the debtor or a related person.
The following dividend income is exempt from tax in the amount of 30%.

The 30% tax on U.S.-sourced dividends you receive from a foreign corporation is not charged. See the "Exception" subsection in the "Dividends" section in Chapter 2 for how to determine U.S.-sourced dividends. This exemption does not apply to payments equivalent to dividends.

The 30% tax on interest-related dividends from United States sources that you receive from a mutual fund or other managed investment company (RIC) is not levied. The mutual fund will determine in writing which dividends are interest-related dividends.

The 30% tax on certain dividends on short-term capital gains from United States sources that you receive from a mutual fund or other managed investment company (RIC) may be waived. The mutual fund will determine in writing which dividends are short-term capital gains dividends. This tax exemption will not apply to you if you are in the United States for 183 days or more during your tax year.
If you are paid by a foreign employer, your income from a U.S. source may be exempt from U.S. tax, but only if you fall into one of the categories discussed below.

If you do not meet all three conditions, your income from domestic services provided in the United States is income from a U.S. source and is subject to taxation under the rules of Chapter 4. If your payment for these services exceeds $3,000, the entire amount is income from professional or commercial activities in the United States.
The term “foreign employer” does not include a foreign government. Payments made by a foreign government that are exempt from U.S. income tax are discussed in Chapter 10.2

Income of any kind exempt from tax in the United States under a treaty to which the United States is a party is excluded from your gross income. However, income that is only subject to tax by treaty is included in your gross income. See Chapter 9.

If you have sold your main home, you may exclude up to $250,000 of the profits from the sale of your home. If you are married and filing jointly, you may exclude up to $500,000. For information on the requirements for this exclusion, see Publication No. 523. This exclusion does not apply if you are subject to the expatriate taxation rules described in Chapter 4.

If you are a degree candidate, you may exclude from your income some or all of the amounts you receive as a qualifying scholarship. The rules discussed here apply to both resident and non-resident foreigners. If a non-resident foreigner receives a scholarship from a non-U.S. source, he or she is not subject to U.S. taxation. See the section "Scholarships, Grants, Awards and Distinctions" in Chapter 2 to determine whether your scholarship or fellowship grant is from U.S. sources. A scholarship or fellowship grant is excluded from income only if... 1. you are a degree candidate at the qualifying institution, and 2. you use the scholarship or fellowship grant to pay for the expenses of qualifying education.

Resident aliens are generally taxed in the same way as U.S. citizens. Non-resident aliens are taxed depending on the source of their income and whether or not their income is actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the U.S. The following material will help you determine whether or not the income you receive during a tax year is actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the U.S. and how it is taxed.

This means that their worldwide income is taxed in the United States and must be reported on their U.S. tax return. Foreign residents' income is subject to the differentiated tax rates that apply to U.S. citizens.

The difference between these two categories is that the actual related income after allowable deductions is taxed at differentiated rates. These are the same rates that apply to U.S. citizens and residents. Income that is not directly related is taxed at a flat rate of 30% (or lower treaty).

u Generally, you must engage in a business during a tax year in order to be able to consider income earned in that year as actually related to that professional or commercial activity. u Whether you engage in a professional or commercial activity in the United States depends on the nature of your activity. u The following discussions will help you determine whether you engage in a professional or commercial activity in the United States. u

If you provide domestic services in the United States at any time during the tax year, you are generally considered to be engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States. Certain remuneration paid to a non-resident alien by a foreign employer is not included in gross income. For more information, see the section "Work Performed for a Foreign Employer" in Chapter 3.

If you are temporarily in the United States as a nonimmigrant on an F, J, M, or Q visa and do not engage in business, you are considered to be engaged in business in the United States if you have taxable income from a scholarship or fellowship grant described in section 1441(b). The taxable portion of any fellowship or fellowship grant that is income from a U.S. source is considered to be actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the U.S.a

If your sole activity in the United States is trading in stocks, securities or commodities (including hedging) through a U.S. resident broker or other agent, you are not engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States. For stocks or securities transactions, this means any non-resident foreigner, including a stocks and securities dealer or broker. For commodity transactions, this means goods that are normally sold and bought on an organized commodity exchange and transactions that are normally conducted on such an exchange. This exception does not apply if you have a U.S. office or other permanent place of business at any time during the tax year through which or at the direction of which you are trading in stocks, securities or commodities.

You are not engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States if trading in stocks, securities or commodities on your own account is your sole activity in the United States. This rule applies even if the trading is carried out while you are in the United States or by your employee, your broker or other agent.

If you are engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States, all income, profits or losses for the tax year that you receive from U.S. sources (except for certain investment income) are considered to be actually related to the U.S. activity. This rule applies regardless of whether there is any connection between the income and the professional or commercial activity carried out in the United States during the tax year.

Use the two tests described below to determine whether income from a U.S. source that falls under one of the three categories and is received during the tax year is actually related to your professional or commercial activity in the U.S. If the tests show that the income is actually related, you should include it as part of other actually related income.
Under this test, if the conduct of a professional or commercial activity in the United States was a substantial factor in the generation of income,a the income is deemed to be actually related.b

If you provide personal services in the United States, you are deemed to be engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States. Personal services income received by you in the tax year in which you engage in a professional or commercial activity in the United States is actually connected to the professional or commercial activity in the United States. Income received in a year other than the year of the services is also actually connected if it would have been actually connected if you received that income in the year of the services. Personal services income includes wages, salaries, commissions, fees, daily allowances, and employee allowances and bonuses. Income may be paid to you in the form of money, services, or property. If you engage in a professional or commercial activity in the United States only because you provide personal services in the United States during the tax year, income and gains from assets, and income and losses from the sale or exchange of capital assets are generally not actually connected to your professional or commercial activity. However, if there is a direct economic connection between the ownership of an asset and the professional or commercial activity of providing personal services, the income, gains, or losses are actually connected.

"Permanent place of business" generally means a place, facility, building or other similar facility through which you engage in professional or commercial activity. "Regular service" means that a ship or aircraft follows a published schedule with repeated flights or missions at regular intervals between the same points for flights or missions that begin or end in the United States.

All profits or losses from U.S. sources derived from conducting business in the U.S. are actually related to professional or commercial activity in the U.S. u For example, profits from the sale in the U.S. of inventory acquired either in that country or in another country are actually related to professional or commercial income. u The portion of the profits or losses from U.S. sources of a corporation engaged in professional or commercial activity in the U.S. is also actually related to professional or commercial activity in the U.S. u u The share of the profits or losses from U.S. sources of a corporation engaged in professional or commercial activity in the U.S. is also actually related to professional or commercial activity in the U.S. u u

This is any interest in real property located in the United States or the U.S. Virgin Islands, or any interest (other than as a creditor) in a national corporation that is a corporation that owns real property in the United States. Real property includes the following. 1. Land and unused natural products of the land, such as growing crops and timber, as well as mines, wells and other natural deposits. 2. Improvements to the land, including buildings, other permanent structures and their structural components. 3.
If you sell a share in a US property, the buyer may have to withhold tax. See the explanation in the subsection "Tax Withheld on Sale of Property" in Chapter 8.

The shares of any domestic corporation are treated as the shares of a U.S. corporation that owns the real estate, unless you prove that the corporation is not a U.S. corporation that owns the real estate.

A U.S. real estate interest does not include a class of corporate shares that are regularly sold and bought on an organized securities market, unless you own more than 5% of the fair market value of that class of shares (or more than 10% of the shares in the case of real estate investment trusts (REITs)).

Special rules apply to qualified investment companies (QIE). A QIE is any real estate investment trust (REIT) or any regulated investment company (RIC) that is considered a U.S. corporation that owns real estate (after application of certain rules in section 897(h)(4)(A)(ii)).

In most cases, any payment from a QIE to a non-resident foreigner, foreign corporation or other QIE that relates to the QIE's profits from the sale or exchange of a U.S. real estate interest is treated as a profit recognized by the non-resident foreigner, foreign corporation or other QIE from the sale or exchange of a U.S. real estate interest.

For the purposes of determining whether a QIE is controlled domestically, the following rules apply. 1. A person holding less than 5% of shares of any class of QIE that are regularly traded and bought on an organized securities market in the United States throughout the verification period will be treated as a U.S. person unless QIE has factual knowledge that such person is not a U.S. person. 2. Any shares of QIE that are owned by another QIE will be treated as owned by a foreign person if... 1. any class of shares of such other QIE is regularly traded and bought on an organized securities market, or 2. such other QIE is a RIC that issues certain redeemable securities.

If you are a direct or indirect foreign partner in a U.S. or foreign corporation that carries on (or is deemed to be carrying on) a professional or commercial activity in the U.S., and you directly or indirectly sell that interest, the gain or loss from the sale of that interest in the corporation may affect your federal tax liability.

Any income from a foreign source that is equivalent to any of the items of income described above is considered to be actually related to a professional or business activity in the United States. For example, interest and dividend equivalents from a foreign source are considered to be actually related to the United States if the income is derived by a foreign person from actively conducting banking, financial or similar business in the United States.i

Income that you receive in a tax year and that is actually related to your professional or commercial activity in the United States is taxed, after allowable deductions, at the rates that apply to U.S. citizens and residents. Generally, you can receive actually related income only if you are a non-resident foreigner engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States during the tax year. However, if you receive payments from the sale or exchange of property, the provision of services, or any other transaction during a tax year in which you are not engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States, but such payments would be considered to be actually related income in the year of the transaction or provision of services, they are treated as actually related income in the tax year in which you received them.
You may be able to classify all income from real estate as income directly related to U.S. activities. See the subsection "Income from Real Estate" later in this section.
Tax at 30% (or lower treaty) applies to certain items of income or profits from U.S. sources, but only if these items are not related to your professional or commercial activities in the U.S.

The 30% rate (or lower by agreement) applies to the gross amount of fixed, determined, annual or periodic (FDAP) profits, revenues or income from a U.S. source. Income is considered fixed when it is paid in amounts known in advance. Income is determined whenever there is a basis for determining the amount payable. Income may be periodic if it is paid from time to time. It does not have to be paid annually or at regular intervals. Income may be determined or periodic even if the duration of the time over which payments are made increases or decreases. Items specifically included as fixed or determined income are interest (other than an initial issue discount (OID)), dividends, payments equivalent to dividends (defined in Chapter 2), rents, bonuses, annuities, wages and other compensation.

Generally, non-resident foreigners are subject to 30% tax on gross gambling income earned in the United States unless such income is directly related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States and is not exempt from tax under a treaty. However, non-commercial gambling income is not subject to tax if a non-resident foreigner wins in the United States at blackjack, baccarat, craps, roulette or the big six wheel.

A non-resident foreigner must include 85% of any social security payments (and the equivalent of the social security of the Tier 1 railroader's pension) in a source of fixed, determined, annual or recurring income in the United States. Social security payments include monthly pension, survivor's and disability benefits. This income is exempt from taxation under certain tax treaties. See Table 1 on the Tax Treaty Tables webpage, available at IRS.gov/TreatyTables for a list of tax treaties that exempt U.S. social security payments from U.S. taxation. For more information, see Publication No. 915.

If you do not engage in a professional or commercial activity in the United States and have not established a tax year for the previous period, your tax year will be a calendar year for the 183-day rule. In addition, you must file a tax return on a calendar year basis. If you were in the United States for less than 183 days during a tax year, gains from the sale of capital assets (other than earlier listed income) are exempt from taxation, unless they are related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States during your tax year.u

If you have income from real property located in the United States that you own in whole or in part and you acquired it for the purpose of earning income, you may treat all income from that property as income actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States. This option applies to all income from real property located in the United States and intended for earning income, and to all income from any interest in such property. This includes income from lease, royalties from mines, oil or gas wells, or other natural resources. It also includes profits from the sale or exchange of timber, coal, or domestic iron ore with a retained economic interest. You may make this option only in respect of real property income that is not otherwise related to your professional or commercial activity in the United States. If you make this option, you are eligible for deductions related to real property income, and only your net real property income will be taxed. This option does not apply to a non-resident alien who is not otherwise engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States as engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States during the year.

This 4% tax applies to your gross transportation income from the United States. This includes only transportation income, which is considered to have been received from United States sources if the transportation starts or ends in the United States. For transportation and domestic services income, the transportation must be between the United States and a territory administered by the United States. For domestic services of a non-resident alien, this applies only to income received from or in any way related to an aircraft.

Under this special rule, you are taxed on gross income and gains from your U.S. source on a net basis at the differentiated rates applicable to individuals (with allowable deductions) for the period during which you were a non-resident alien, unless you are subject to a higher tax under section 871 (the rules that normally apply to the taxation of non-resident aliens are discussed above) after taking into account any applicable treaty benefits.

If you are liable for this tax for any year during the period you were a non-resident alien, you must file a Form 1040-NR for that year. The tax return must be filed within the deadline (including an extension) for filing your U.S. income tax return for the year you become a U.S. resident again. If you have already filed returns for that period, you must file amended returns. You must attach to your return a statement showing the source of all your gross U.S. and foreign income, as well as the items of income that fall under this special rule.

You must file an initial Form 8854 in the year you renounce U.S. citizenship or terminate your long-term residence, even if you are not liable to pay expatriate tax. In addition, you must file a Form 8854 annually after your expatriation if you were liable to pay expatriate tax and... 1. you have deferred the payment of current market value tax (see the subsection "Deferred payment of current market value tax" below), 2. you have deferred compensation titles, or 3. you are entitled to receive income from the assets of trusts without a trustee.

If you emigrated after June 16, 2008, you are considered a protected expatriate and the expatriation rules under section 877A apply to you if you meet any of the following conditions. 1. Your average annual net income tax for the 5 years ended prior to the date of departure or termination of residence is more than $201,000 on expatriation or termination of residence in the United States in 2024. 2. Your equity is $2 million or more on the date of departure or termination of residence. 3. You do not verify on Form 8854 that you have met all your U.S. federal tax obligations for the 5 years preceding the date of your departure or termination of residence.

In the year you leave the United States, you are liable to income tax on the net unrealized gain (or loss) in your property as if the property had been sold at fair market value the day before you left the United States. This applies to most types of property interest that you owned on the date of renunciation or cessation of residence.

Instead, in the case of (1) and (3), tax may be withheld initially. In the case of (2), you are deemed to receive the current value of your accrued benefits for the day prior to the date of your expatriation. In the case of (4), you are deemed to receive a distribution of your entire share in the account for the day prior to the date of your expatriation. For more information, see Notice 2009-85 and the instructions for Form 8854.

Once you have determined your U.S. residential alien status, the source of your income, and whether (and how) that income is taxed in the United States, your next step will be to calculate your tax. The information in this chapter is not as comprehensive for U.S. residential aliens as for non-resident aliens.

Non-resident aliens may claim the same item deductions as resident aliens. However, non-resident aliens may only claim item deductions if they have income actually related to their professional or commercial activity in the United States. There may be limitations on the amount of item deductions you can claim in Schedule A. See the instructions for Schedule A (Form 1040) or the instructions for Schedule A (Form 1040-NR) "Item Deductions" in the instructions for Form 1040-NR.

You can claim the same item-by-item deductions as U.S. citizens using Schedule A (Form 1040). See the instructions for Schedule A (Form 1040) for more information. If you do not specify your deductions item-by-item, you can claim the standard deduction for your specific filing status. See the instructions for Form 1040 for more information.

You can deduct certain itemized deductions if you earn income that is actually related to your professional or commercial activity in the United States. As a rule, you can only include deductions and/or losses that are properly allocated and proportionate to the income that is actually related to your professional or commercial activity in the United States.

Non-resident foreigners cannot claim the standard deduction. However, there is a special rule for certain foreigners from India who are temporarily residing in the United States, as described below:11

Special rules apply to students and business interns who are eligible for benefits under Article 21(2) of the U.S.-India Double Taxation Agreement. You can claim a standard deduction provided you do not claim item-by-item deductions. Use Worksheet 5-1 to calculate your standard deduction for 2024. If you are married and your spouse files a tax return and declares item-by-item deductions, you cannot use the standard deduction.

If you are a student or business intern eligible for relief under Article 21(2) of the U.S.-India Double Taxation Agreement who has been affected by certain major federal disasters in 2024 (see IRS.gov/DisasterTaxRelief and FEMA.gov/Disasters), you may elect to increase your standard deduction for any qualifying personal disaster losses on your 2024 tax return.

You can deduct state and local income tax that you paid on income actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States. Your deduction is limited to $10,000 ($5,000 for married individuals filing separately). If you received a refund or overpayment refund on taxes paid in the previous year, do not deduct that amount. Instead, you must include the refund or overpayment refund in your income if you deducted taxes in the previous year and the deduction reduced your tax. For details on how to calculate the amount to include in your income, see the “Refunds” section in Publication #525.

You may, with some restrictions, deduct charitable donations or gifts to eligible organizations. Eligible organizations include religious, charitable, educational, scientific or literary organizations, and organizations working to prevent child or animal abuse. Some organizations that promote national or international amateur sports also meet the eligibility criteria. For more information on deducting charitable contributions, see the section "Gifts to U.S. Charities" in the instructions for Schedule A (Form 1040-NR) "Artikelspecifieke aftrekposten" and in the instructions for Form 1040-NR.

You can deduct accident and theft losses on your tax return. You can deduct a non-commercial accident or theft loss only if it is caused by a federally defined natural disaster. If the accident or theft occurred to you as a result of a federally defined natural disaster, you can deduct the loss even if your property is not related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States.

For more information, see the instructions for line 7 in the Instructions for Schedule A (Form 1040-NR) “Item Deductions” in the Instructions for Form 1040-NR. See also Publication No. 529, or the IRS’s website.

You may claim a credit, subject to certain limitations, for income tax you paid or were assessed in a foreign state on income from a foreign source. You cannot claim a credit for taxes paid or assessed on excluded foreign income. To claim a credit for income tax paid or assessed in a foreign state, you must usually complete Form 1116 together with Form 1040 or 1040-SR. For more information, see Publication No. 514.

An adopted child is a child who has been legally adopted by a person. If a person does not have an SNN (or ITIN) issued on or before the 2024 tax return date (including extensions), such person cannot claim a child tax credit and an additional child tax credit on the original 2024 tax return or on an amended tax return.

The Other Dependants Credit is for people who have dependents and who are not eligible for a child tax credit. An eligible dependent must be a U.S. citizen, unincorporated citizen or resident alien and must have an SSN, ITIN or ATIN issued no later than the date of your 2024 tax return (including extensions).

You may be eligible for a tax credit of up to $16,810 for qualifying expenses for adopting a qualifying child. If you adopt a child with special needs, the credit may be claimed regardless of whether you incurred qualifying expenses. To apply for an adoption expense credit, file Form 8839 with Form 1040 or 1040-SR.

To qualify for an EIC, you must have income from working for someone or running or owning a business or farm and meet the basic rules. In addition, you must either meet the additional rules for employees who do not have a qualifying child or have a child who meets all of the qualifying criteria for children. The EIC reduces the amount of tax you owe and can help you get your refund. For more information, visit IRS.gov/EIC. If you (or, in the case of joint tax returns, your spouse(s)) did not have an SSN issued before or on the 2024 tax return deadline or earlier (including renewals), you cannot claim an EIC on either your original return or your 2024 amended return. Furthermore, if the child did not have an SSN issued before or on the 2024 amended return or earlier (including renewals), you cannot count that child as a qualifying child in calculating the EIC on either your original return or your 2024 amended return. If your Social Security card has a “Not Eligible for Employment” label and the number was issued to enable you (or your spouse or qualifying child) to receive federal benefits, you cannot claim an EIC. An example of a federally funded benefit is Medicaid. If the card has this label and the person’s immigration status has changed to make them a U.S. citizen or a legal permanent resident, ask your IRS to refund the EIC.
Credits are only allowed if you earn income that is actually related to your business activity in the United States.

If you have income from a foreign source that is actually related to a professional or business activity in the United States, you may be entitled to a refund of U.S. tax on taxes paid or assessed in a foreign state or territory administered by the United States. You may not be credited for taxes levied by a foreign state or territory administered by the United States on your income from a U.S. source if those taxes were levied solely because you are a citizen or resident of a foreign state or territory.

You may be eligible for this credit if you pay someone to care for your qualifying dependent child under 13 years of age, or for your disabled dependent or disabled spouse, so that you can work or seek employment. See Publication No. 503 for definitions of these terms. Married non-resident foreigners may only qualify for the credit if they elect to file a joint tax return with a U.S. citizen or resident spouse as described in the section "How to make a choice" in Chapter 1, or if they are married and live separately (see the "Joint Tax Return Test" section in Publication No. 503).

An adopted child is a child legally adopted by a person. If you did not have an SSN (or ITIN) issued before or on the 2024 tax return deadline (including extensions), you cannot claim a child tax credit on either your original return or your amended return. If your child did not have a valid employment SSN issued before or on the 2024 tax return deadline (including extensions), you cannot claim a child tax credit for that child, but you can claim a credit for other dependents for that child. See the "Tax Credit Payable for Other Dependants" section discussed below. Use Schedule 8812 (Form 1040) to calculate the amounts of credits.

This is a non-refundable tax credit of $500 per eligible person. An eligible dependent must be a U.S. citizen, resident of an unincorporated territory (e.g., American Samoa) or a resident alien. See the instructions for Form 1040-NR. To qualify for the credit for other dependants, your dependent must have an SSN, ITIN or ATIN issued no later than the 2024 tax return deadline (including extensions).

If you are adopting a child with special needs, you may be eligible for a tax credit of up to $16,810 regardless of whether you incurred eligible expenses. To claim an adoption credit, file Form 8839 with your Form 1040-NR. Married non-resident foreigners may only qualify for a credit if they elect to file jointly with a U.S. citizen spouse or a resident spouse as described in the "Non-resident spouse treated as a resident" section in Chapter 1, or if the spouses qualify as certain married persons living separately (see the "Married Persons filing separately" section in the Form 8839 instructions).
If you paid the alternative minimum tax in the previous year, use Form 8801 and its instructions to find out if you are eligible for this credit.

If you are a non-resident foreigner for any part of the tax year, you are generally not eligible for an earned income credit (EIC). However, if you are married and choose to file jointly with a U.S. citizen spouse or a resident spouse as described in the "Non-resident spouse treated as a resident" section in Chapter 1, you may be eligible for an EIC. If you or your spouse did not have an SSN issued before or on the 2024 tax return filing date (including extensions), you cannot count that child as qualifying for an EIC either on the original return or on the 2024 amendment return.

You can claim that the tax withheld during the year is used to pay your U.S. tax. Provide the relevant information on lines 25a through 25g of Form 1040-NR. The withheld tax reduces the amount of any tax you are required to pay under Form 1040-NR.

Any federal income tax withheld on your salary during the tax year when you were a non-resident alien is admissible as a payment against your U.S. income tax liability for that year. You may claim that the tax withheld during the year is used to pay your U.S. tax, u regardless of whether you engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States during the year and whether the salary (or any other income) was related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States.

Your employer is responsible for withholding 0.9% (0.009) of the additional Medicare tax on wages or railway pensions (RRTA) that exceed $200,000 in 2024. If you do not owe additional Medicare tax, you can claim a credit for any additional Medicare tax withheld against the total tax liability shown on your tax return by completing Form 8959.

You may use as a payment any tax withheld before payment on investments or on other fixed or determined annual or periodic income paid to you. Fixed or determined income includes interest, dividends, rent and royalties that you do not actually refer to as tied income.

If you are a foreign partner in a partnership, the partnership will withhold tax on your share of the partnership's actual related taxable income. The partnership will provide you with a Form 8805 report showing the withheld tax. A partnership whose shares are sold and bought on the stock exchange may withhold taxes from the amount of the distribution of your actual related income.

If you are a direct or indirect foreign partner in a U.S. or foreign corporation that engages (or is considered to engage) in a professional or commercial activity in the United States and you dispose of that interest directly or indirectly for profit, for transfers after 2017, the recipient will generally withhold and pay to the IRS on your behalf tax equal to 10% of the amount realized on the sale. The rules for withholding and paying in excess of that amount are similar to those for the sale of U.S. real estate interests. You will receive a Form 8288-A reflecting the withheld amount, which you can then claim on line 25f of your Form 1040-NR as a deduction for the tax you owe on the profits. You can provide the recipient with certain information to reduce or eliminate the withholding. For example, if the Tax Code’s profit withholding provision applies to all of the profits earned on the transfer, the recipient may not have to withhold tax if you provide a notice stating that the profit withholding provision is applied. If you are the recipient and your tax has not been withheld, the corporation may withhold tax on the distribution of income. The U.S. Treasury Department decision (T.D. 9926 (85 FR 76910/2020-51_IRS#TD-9926), published on November 30, 2020 (as amended in 86 FR 13191), contains final regulations (1446(f) regulations) for the withholding of income tax on the transfer.

You may use any tax withheld in connection with the waiver of a U.S. real estate interest (or income treated as having been received as a result of the waiver of a U.S. real estate interest) as a payment. See the "Profit or loss on real property" section in Chapter 4. The buyer will provide you with a report of the amount withheld on Form 8288-A. Report the tax withheld as a payment on line 25f of Form 1040-NR.

If you are a non-resident alien who is a valid resident of American Samoa or Puerto Rico for the entire tax year, you are generally taxed in the same way as resident aliens. You should file Form 1040 or 1040-SR and disclose information on all income from both U.S. and non-U.S. sources. However, you may exclude the income described in the following paragraphs. However, for tax purposes other than income reporting, you will be treated as a non-resident alien. For example, you are not allowed a standard deduction, you cannot file a joint return, and you cannot disclose a dependent unless the person is a U.S. citizen or a resident of an unincorporated territory. There are also restrictions on what deductions and credits are allowed. See the “Non-resident aliens” subsection in the “Deductions” and “Artikel Deductions” sections, and also the “Tax Credits and Payments” section in this chapter.

If you are a valid resident of Puerto Rico for the whole year, you may exclude from your gross income all income from sources in Puerto Rico (except for amounts for services rendered as an employee of the United States or any of its agencies). If you report income for a calendar year and you do not have any withholding income in 2024, file and pay tax by June 16, 2025. You must also make your first withholding tax payment for 2025 by June 16, 2024. You cannot file a joint income tax return or make joint withholding tax payments. However, if you are married to a U.S. citizen or resident, see the "Non-resident spouse treated as a resident" section in Chapter 1.

If you have not previously established a fiscal year, your tax year will be a calendar year. A calendar year is 12 consecutive months ending on December 31. If you have previously established a standard fiscal year (12 consecutive months ending on the last day of a month other than December, or a 52-53 week year) and consider yourself a U.S. resident during any calendar year, you will be considered a U.S. resident for any part of the fiscal year that falls into that calendar year.

A taxpayer identification number (TIN) must be provided on tax returns, returns and other tax documents. For an individual, it is a Social Security Number (SSN). If you do not have an SSN and are not eligible for one, you must apply for an Individual Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN). An Employer Identification Number (EIN) is required if you are engaged in a profession or business as a sole proprietor and have employees or a qualifying pension plan. You must provide a taxpayer identification number (TIN) if you are... an alien whose income is directly related to a profession or business in the United States at any time during the year; an alien who has an office or place of business in the United States at any time during the year; a non-resident spouse considered a resident as discussed in Chapter 1; or any other alien who files a tax return, amendment tax return or tax refund claim (but not a disclosure return).

If you have not used your ITIN on a federal tax return at least once for the 2021, 2022 or 2023 tax year, it will expire on December 31, 2024, and if you need to file a federal tax return for 2024, you will need to renew your ITIN. You do not need to update your ITIN if you do not need to file a federal tax return. To update your ITIN, see Form W-7 and its instructions at IRS.gov/FormW7. For more information, see IRS.gov/ITIN. ITINs issued prior to 2013 have expired, and if you need to file a 2024 tax return, they need to be renewed. If you have previously applied for an extension and it has been approved, you do not need to renew it again if you have not used your ITIN on a federal tax return at least once for the 2021, 2022 or 2023 tax year.

Your tax status is important in determining whether you can file for certain deductions and credits. The rules for determining your filing status are different for resident and non-resident foreigners.

If your spouse died in 2022 or 2023 and you did not remarry before the end of 2024, you may be eligible to file as a tax-eligible widow/widower and use joint tax rates. This applies only if you were able to file a joint tax return with your spouse for the year of his/her death. For details on the filing status of a tax-eligible widow/widower, see the subsection “Tax-eligible widow/widower” in the “Tax Status” section of the 2024 Form 1040 instructions.

Non-resident foreigners married but not to U.S. citizens or residents should usually use the Married and Separately Filed Tax Calculator Worksheet when determining income tax on income actually related to professional or commercial activities in the U.S.

Married non-resident aliens are generally not eligible to use the Tax Grid or the Unmarried Tax Calculation Worksheet. However, you may file as an unmarried person if you have lived separately from your spouse for the past 6 months of the year and you are a married resident of Canada, Mexico, or South Korea, or a married resident of an unincorporated territory. See the instructions for Form 1040-NR to find out if you are eligible. The definition of an unincorporated territory resident is given below in this section. A non-resident alien is generally not eligible to file a joint tax return. However, a non-resident alien married to a U.S. citizen or resident may choose to be a resident and file a joint tax return using Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR. For details on these options, see Chapter 1. If you choose not to file a joint tax return, complete Form 1040-NR and use the Tax Grid or the Unmarried Tax Calculation Worksheet for Married Individuals filing separate tax returns.

If your spouse died in 2022 or 2023 and you did not marry before the end of 2024, you may be eligible to file as a tax-eligible widow/widower and use the tax rates of joint tax filing. For details on the tax status of a tax-eligible widow/widower, see the “Tax-eligible Widow/Widower” subsection of the Tax Status section and the instructions for Form 1040-NR for 2024.

A non-resident foreigner's estate or trust using Form 1040-NR must use the Tax Rates Schedule W in the Form 1040-NR instructions when determining income tax on income actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States.

You must report on each item of income that is subject to taxation under the provisions of the law in chapters 2, 3, and 4. For foreign residents, this includes income from sources both in the United States and abroad. For non-resident foreigners, this includes both income that is actually related to professional or commercial activity in the United States (subject to differentiated tax rates) and income from sources in the United States that is not actually related (subject to a flat tax rate of 30% or a lower rate under a double taxation agreement).

You may claim deductions to calculate your taxable income directly related to your U.S. business (ECTI). As a general rule, you cannot claim deductions related to income not related to your U.S. business. The exceptions are certain item-by-item deductions discussed below. You may claim deductions only to the extent that they relate to income related to your U.S. business.

If you have income that is actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States, you may deduct up to 20% of your qualifying income from a qualifying professional or commercial activity, plus 20% of your qualifying dividends from a qualifying REIT and a qualifying PTP. For more information, see line 13a in the instructions for Form 1040-NR. For more information on the deduction from qualifying business income, see Form 8995, Form 8995-A and their annexes, and the appropriate instructions for the forms and annexes.

If you made contributions to a traditional IRA for 2024, you can report this deduction on your tax return. But to do so, you must have taxable compensation actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States. Form 5498 must be sent to you by June 2, 2025; it will list all contributions to your traditional IRA for 2024. If you were insured under a retirement plan (qualifying pension, profit-sharing (including 401(k)), annuity, SEP, SIMPLE, etc.), employment or self-employment, your IRA deduction may be reduced or cancelled. But you can still make contributions to a traditional IRA even if you cannot deduct them. If you made non-taxable contributions to a traditional IRA for 2024, you must report them on Form 8606. For more information, see Publication No. 590-A.

Do not include in income the cost of removal and storage services provided by the Government due to the relocation in accordance with the transfer to a new permanent duty station. Similarly, do not include in income amounts received as relocation allowances, temporary living expenses, temporary living allowances or tax credits for housing. For more information, see Publication No. 311.

You must include in your income all actual related interest income that you receive or that is credited to your account during the year. Do not reduce it by any penalty you are required to pay for early withdrawals from a savings account. However, if the interest income is actually related to your professional or commercial activity in the United States during the year, you may deduct on line 18 of Schedule 1 (Form 1040) the amount of the early withdrawal penalty charged by the bank. Attach Schedule 1 (Form 1040) to your Form 1040-NR.

If you do not provide a dependent's SSN, ITIN or individual taxpayer number for adopted child (ATIN) in the "Dependents" section of your tax return, or if you provide an incorrect number, some tax benefits may not be available.

If you are a resident alien, your child or eligible relative may be a legal dependent. For a child to qualify, you must pass five tests. For a person to qualify as your eligible relative, you must pass four tests. For more information, see the instructions for Form 1040. If you do not provide a dependent's SSN, ITIN or ATIN in the "Dependents" section of your tax return, or if you provide an incorrect number, some tax benefits may not be available. See the "Identification Number" section above.

You are considered to have a dual-status tax year if you were a resident alien and a non-resident alien in the same year. Dual-status does not apply to your citizenship; it only applies to your status as a U.S. resident for tax purposes. In determining your U.S. income tax liability for a dual-status tax year, different rules apply for the part of the year in which you are a U.S. resident and the part of the year in which you are a non-resident.

If you are a resident on the last day of the tax year and report your income each calendar year, you must file your tax return by April 15 of the year following your tax year (see Tip (TIP) below). If your tax year is not a calendar year, you must file your tax return by the 15th of the fourth month following your tax year. In both cases, you must file your tax return at the dual-residency address within one tax year, as indicated on the cover of the instructions for Form 1040. If you are a non-resident on the last day of the tax year and report your income each calendar year, you must file your tax return by April 15 of the year following your tax year if you receive a salary that is subject to withholding tax. If you report your income in a manner other than each calendar year, you must file your tax return by the 15th of the fourth month following your tax year. If you have not received a salary that is subject to withholding tax and report your income each calendar year, you must file your tax return by June 15 of the year following your tax year. If you report your income in a manner other than each calendar year, you must file your tax return by the 15th of the sixth month following your tax year.
