In any case, you must send your tax return to the following address: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Austin, TX 73301-0215 If you attach a receipt of payment to your tax return, you must send both the receipt of payment and the return.

If you have not previously established a fiscal year, your tax year is a calendar year. A calendar year is 12 consecutive months ending on December 31. If you have previously established a regular fiscal year (12 consecutive months ending on the last day of a month other than December, or a 52-53 week year) and are considered a U.S. resident for any calendar year, you will be considered a U.S. resident for any part of your fiscal year that falls within that calendar year.

During the part of the year when you are a foreign resident, you are taxed on income from all sources. Income from sources outside the United States is taxed if you received it while you were a foreign resident. Income is taxed even if you earned it while you were a non-resident alien or if you became a non-resident alien after you received it and before the end of the year. During the part of the year when you are a foreign non-resident, you are taxed on income from sources in the United States and on certain income from foreign sources that is considered to be actually related to a professional or business activity in the United States. The rules for treating income from foreign sources as actually related are discussed in the Foreign Income section in Chapter 4. Income from sources outside the United States that is not actually related to a professional or business activity in the United States is not taxed if you receive it while you are a non-resident alien. Income is not taxed even if you earned it while you were a non-resident alien or if you became a resident alien or a U.S. citizen after you received it and before the end of the year. Income from sources in the United States is taxed whether you receive it as a non-resident alien or a resident alien unless it is specifically exempt from tax under the Tax Code or a tax treaty provision. In general, the tax treaty provisions apply only to the part of the year in which you were a non-resident. However, in some cases, treaty provisions may apply when you were a resident alien. For more information, see Chapter 9.
The following limitations apply if you file a tax return for a tax year with dual status.
You cannot use the standard deduction allowed on Form 1040 or 1040-SR. However, you can specify any allowable item-by-item deductions.

As a dual-status taxpayer, you may list a dependent on your tax return. Typically, the dependent is a qualifying child or qualifying relative. You may be eligible for additional deductions and credits if you have a qualifying dependent. For more information, see the Form 1040 instructions or the Form 1040-NR instructions. If you were a resident of an unincorporated territory or lived in Canada or Mexico, you may list a dependent under the same conditions as U.S. citizens. If you are a resident of South Korea or India, see Chapter 5.
When you calculate your U.S. tax for a dual-status year, you are subject to different rules for the part of the year that you are a resident and the part of the year that you are a non-resident.

All income from your residence and all income that is actually related to a professional or commercial activity in the United States during your non-residence, after allowable deductions, is added and taxed at the rates that apply to U.S. citizens and residents.

During the part of the year you are a non-resident alien, 85% of any U.S. Social Security payments (and equivalent part of Tier 1 railway pension payments) you receive are taxed at a flat rate of 30% unless you are exempt or subject to a lower treaty rate. (See "Tax at 30%" in Chapter 4.) During the part of the year you are a resident alien, the portion of the Social Security payments and equivalent part of Tier 1 railway pension payments will be taxed at differentiated rates if your adjusted gross income plus half of those payments exceeds a certain base amount. Use the Social Security Payments worksheet in the Form 1040 instructions to help you determine the taxable portion of your U.S. Social Security payments and equivalent Tier 1 railway pension payments for the part of the year you were a resident alien. If you received U.S. Social Security payments as a non-resident alien, the Social Security Administration (SSA) will send you Form SSA-1042S showing your total payments for the whole year and the amount of tax withheld. You will not receive separate reports of the payments received during your residency and non-residency. Therefore, it is important for you to keep a careful record of these amounts. This information is necessary to complete your return correctly and determine your tax liability.

As a dual-status alien, you can generally claim tax credits using the same rules that apply to resident aliens. There are certain restrictions that may apply. These restrictions are discussed here, along with a brief explanation of the credits that are often claimed by individuals. You cannot claim an educational tax credit, an earned income credit (EIC), or an elderly or disabled persons credit unless you are married and have chosen to be considered a U.S. resident for the duration of 2024 by filing a joint return with your spouse who is a U.S. citizen or resident, as described in Chapter 1.

You may qualify for this credit if you pay someone to care for your dependent child under 13 years of age or your disabled dependent or disabled spouse so that you can work or seek employment. Married foreigners with dual status may only qualify for the credit if they choose to file a joint return as described in Chapter 1, or if they qualify for a certain category of married and separated persons. The amount of care expenses for your child and dependants that qualify for the credit in any tax year cannot exceed your earned income for that tax year. For more information, see Publication No. 503 and Form 2441.

An adopted child is a child who has been legally adopted by a taxpayer. If you do not have a Social Security account number (or individual taxpayer identification number) issued at or before the 2024 tax return deadline (including extensions), you cannot claim a tax credit for the child on the original 2024 tax return or any amendments.

The Other Dependant Credit is for people who have dependents and who are not eligible for a child tax credit. An eligible dependent must be a U.S. citizen, unincorporated resident, or resident alien and must have an SSN, ITIN, or ATIN (individual taxpayer number for an adopted child) issued no later than the filing date of your 2024 tax return (including extensions). For more information, see Schedule 8812 (Form 1040) and its instructions.

You may be eligible for a tax credit of up to $16,810 for eligible expenses for the adoption of a qualifying child. This amount may also be paid for the adoption of a child with special needs regardless of eligible expenses. To receive this tax credit, file Form 8839 with your U.S. income tax return.

You may report taxes paid, taxes credited as paid, or taxes withheld from your salary as payments to your U.S. income tax liability. Such taxes include... taxes withheld from wages received for activities in the U.S., taxes withheld from various sources of income from activities in the U.S. other than wages, the assessed tax paid on Form 1040-ES or Form 1040-ES (NR), and the tax paid on Form 1040-C on departure from the U.S.

The U.S. individual income tax return you must file as a person with dual resident and non-resident status in the same tax year depends on whether you are a resident or a non-resident at the end of that tax year.

If you are a dual-status taxpayer who became a resident during the year and are a resident on the last day of the tax year, you must file Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR. Enter a "Dual-Status Return" at the top of the return. To report income for the year you were a non-resident, attach a statement to your tax return. You can use Form 1040-NR as a return, where you must enter a "Dual-Status Statement" at the top of the form.

If you are a taxpayer who renounces your status as a resident during the year and are not a resident on the last day of the year, you must file Form 1040-NR. Enter a "Dual-Status Return" at the top of the tax return. To report on your income during the year you were a resident, attach a statement to your tax return. You can use either Form 1040 or 1040-SR as a statement, where you must enter a "Dual-Status Statement" at the top of the form. If you renounced your citizenship or lost your status as a resident in 2024, you may need to file a renouncement statement (Form 8854) with your tax return. For more information, see the "Expatriation Tax" section in Chapter 4.

The deadline for filing and paying the tax is April 15 of the year following the year for which you filed your tax return (see Tip (TIP) above). Under U.S. immigration law, a resident alien who is required to file a tax return as a resident alien and does not do so may be considered to have renounced his or her resident alien status and may lose it.

If you file Form 4868 by the tax filing deadline, you will be eligible for an automatic extension of 6 months (up to October 15 for taxpayers reporting income each calendar year). For more information, see Form 4868. If you file a tax return automatically extended by 6 months, your tax filing deadline does not extend. If you have not paid your tax by the original tax filing deadline, you will incur interest on the outstanding tax. Also, penalties may apply. If your company is located and your place of residence is outside the U.S. and Puerto Rico on April 15, your tax filing deadline is automatically extended to June 15. If you require more time at the end of the two-month period, you may obtain an additional extension of 4 months until October 15 if you file Form 4868 by June 15. In addition to the 6-month extension, non-US taxpayers (as defined in the Form 4868 instructions) may, at their discretion, request an additional 2-month extension of the tax filing deadline (up to December 15 for taxpayers reporting income each calendar year). To request an additional extension of the deadline, you must send the IRS a letter explaining why you require the additional 2 months. The letter must be sent by the extension deadline (up to October 15 for taxpayers reporting income each calendar year) to the address below. Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Center Austin, TX 73301-

You must also file a tax return if you want to... claim a refund of excessively withheld wages or overpaid taxes, or to apply for any tax deductions or credits. For example, if you do not have any economic activity in the United States, but you receive income from real estate that you claim as income from an activity in the United States (as described in Chapter 4), you must file a true and completed tax return on time to receive any authorized deductions on such income.

If a foreign person wholly owns a non-corporate entity located in the United States, such entity is considered a U.S. corporation separate from its owner (a foreign person) for the purposes of the requirements of Section 6038A, which apply to 25% of corporations located in the United States and owned by foreigners. A non-corporate entity located in the United States and owned by foreigners must file the standard Form 1120 and Form 5472 in the appendix to the tax return before the filing deadline (including extensions). The Form 1120 only requires the name and address of the non-corporate entity located in the United States and owned by foreigners, and must complete Sections B and E in the first part of the document. If a non-corporate entity located in the United States and owned by foreigners has been engaged in professional, commercial or other reportable activities in the United States, it may have been subject to the reporting requirement before 2017. For additional information and affiliation with Form 5472 to be filed by a non-corporate entity located in the United States and owned by foreigners, see the instructions for Form 5472. Also note: Since a non-corporate entity located in the United States and owned by foreigners is generally a tax-transparent entity, the foreign person must disclose (or will continue to disclose) on Form 1040-NR any information that is relevant to the entity.

If you are an employee and receive a piece wage that is subject to U.S. income tax withholding, you must generally file your tax return by the 15th of the fourth month after the end of your tax year. Thus, for the 2024 calendar year you must file your tax return by April 15, 2025. If you are not an employee and do not receive a piece wage that is subject to U.S. income tax withholding, you must file your tax return by the 15th of the sixth month after the end of your tax year. Thus, for the 2024 calendar year you must file your tax return by June 16, 2025.

If you are unable to file your tax return on time, file Form 4868 or use one of the electronic filing methods listed in the Form 4868 instructions. Thus, for the 2024 calendar year, you will be able to extend your tax return deadline to October 15, 2025. If your tax return deadline is June 16, 2025, you will be able to extend your tax return deadline to December 15, 2025. You must file the tax return deadline extension form before the tax return deadline.

The following tax credits are not subject to this filing deadline: Tax credit for withholding taxes Tax credit for federal tax on certain types of gasoline and special fuels Tax credit for tax paid by a collective investment fund (or other regulated investment companies) or a real estate investment trust on long-term retained profits.

If your U.S. activity was restricted and you are satisfied that you did not earn any gross income from U.S. professional or commercial activities during the year, you may file a tax-free organization return (Form 1040-NR) by the deadline set out above. By filing this return, you protect your right to deductions and credits if it is later determined that some or all of your income is actually related to U.S. professional or commercial activities. You are not required to report any income directly related to U.S. professional or commercial activities or deductions on the tax-free organization return, but you must justify the need to file this return. If you believe that an activity has earned you income directly related to U.S. professional or commercial activities, you must file a tax return by the original deadline that reports such income and related deductions. To protect your right to deductions or credits for other activities, you must attach a statement to your tax return that requires you to explain that you want to protect your right to such deductions and credits if it is later determined that those activities have earned you income directly related to U.S. professional or commercial activities. If you believe that you are not tax-free from U.S. activities under a tax treaty, you may do the same. You must also complete box L of Schedule OI (Form 1040-NR).

If you prove that you acted in good faith, reasonably in the facts and circumstances, to fail to file a U.S. income tax return (including a tax return for non-taxable organizations), and will cooperate with the IRS to determine your U.S. income tax liability for the tax year for which you failed to file a tax return, the IRS may disregard the missed tax filing deadline.

If you are a valid resident of the U.S. Virgin Islands for the entirety of your tax year and are working temporarily in the U.S., you must pay U.S. Virgin Islands income tax and file your income tax return at the following address: Virgin Islands Bureau of Internal Revenue 6115 Estate Smith Bay Suite 225 St. Thomas, VI 00802. Chapter 8 describes the withholding of taxes from U.S. piece wages of U.S. Virgin Islands residents.

If you noticed changes in your income, deductions or tax credits after filing your tax return, you must file Form 1040-X. If you were supposed to file Form 1040-NR instead of Form 1040-SR, or vice versa, you must also use Form 1040-X. If you are amending a Form 1040-NR or filing a correct tax return, enter “Amended” at the top of the document and attach the amended tax return (Form 1040, 1040-SR or 1040-NR) to your Form 1040-X. As a general rule, you must file an amended tax return within 3 years of the tax filing date or within 2 years of the tax payment date, whichever is later.

You must file Form 8938 if the total value of these assets exceeds a specified threshold (the “reporting threshold”). The reporting threshold depends on whether you are a resident of the United States, married, or filing a joint income tax return with your spouse. The specified foreign financial assets include any financial account maintained by a foreign financial institution. They also include any shares, securities or other interests held for investment purposes in a foreign organization, and any financial instrument or contract with an issuer or counterparty that is not a U.S. entity.

If you fail to file your tax return and pay the tax on time, you may be fined. You may also be fined if you substantially understate the tax amount, file unfounded tax documents, and fail to provide your taxpayer identification number (TIN). If you have provided false information in your tax return, you may be fined for tax fraud.

If you fail to file your tax return by the deadline (including extensions), you will have to pay a non-filing penalty. The penalty is based on the taxes not paid by the deadline (excluding extensions).

If the item in your return is related to a tax haven, the tax reduction for adequate disclosure is not made. However, the tax reduction is made for the indication of an authoritative source, but only in the event that you reasonably believed that the tax accounting you applied was correct.

The availability of a reference to an authoritative source for the tax accounting of a particular item depends on a variety of facts and circumstances. These sources may include court rulings, U.S. Treasury Department regulations, income rulings, tax proceedings, and notices and announcements issued by the IRS and published in the IRS Bulletin that attest to circumstances similar to yours.

You will not have to pay a fine if you justify the way in which you have recorded a particular item (provide a valid reason). You must also prove that you have acted in good faith. This provision does not apply to transactions that do not make economic sense.

If you file an incorrect refund or credit request, you may be fined 20% of the amount for which you were denied. However, no penalty will be imposed if you prove that you had a valid reason for making the request. However, any denied requests for transactions that do not make economic sense will be considered as having no valid reason.

If you file a false tax return or other false tax documents, you may be fined up to $5,000. A false tax return is a return that contains insufficient information to determine the correct tax amount or contains information that clearly shows that the tax amount stated is incorrect. For more information on false tax returns, false tax documents and a list of items designated as false, see IRS.gov/irb/2010-17_IRB#NOT-2010-33 (or later). You will be fined for filing such tax returns or tax documents due to your false position or to your desire to delay or impede the enforcement of federal tax laws. This includes altering or deleting pre-printed text above the field for your signature. This penalty is in addition to other penalties provided by law.
If there is a tax deduction on your tax return due to tax fraud, a penalty of 75% of the amount of the deduction will be added to your tax.

If you fail to provide your Social Security Number (SSN) or Individual Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN) or SSN or another person's ITIN in the appropriate fields of a tax return, report or other document, you will be fined $50 per pass. You may also be fined $50 if you fail to provide your SSN or ITIN to a bank if you have an interest-bearing account.
If the reason for the non-submission of the tax return was tax fraud, the penalty is 15% for each full or incomplete month of delay in the filing of the tax return, but not more than 75%lite.
If you file your tax return more than 60 days after the tax return deadline or the tax return deadline with extension, you will be fined $510 or 100% of the amount of unpaid tax, whichever is less.
you will not have to pay a fine if you prove that you failed to file your tax return on time for a valid reason and not because of intentional negligence.

You will have to pay a penalty of ½ of 1% (0.005) of the amount of unpaid tax for each full or incomplete month after the tax deadline. This penalty does not apply during the automatic 6-month extension period if you have paid at least 90% of the actual amount of your tax liability until the deadline for your tax return and you pay the balance on filing. The monthly penalty rate for non-payment of tax is half the standard rate of 1/4% (0.0025 instead of ½% (0.005)) if there is an installment agreement in effect in that month. You must file your tax return on time (including extension periods) to qualify for the reduced penalty rate. In the case of a notice of intent to charge tax, the rate increases by 1% at the beginning of the first month beginning at least 10 days after the date of the notice.

If both the default penalty and the non-payment penalty (see above) are applied in the same month, the default penalty of 5% (or 15%) is reduced by the amount of the default penalty. However, if you file your tax return more than 60 days after the tax return deadline or the tax return deadline after extension, you will be fined $510 or 100% of the amount of the unpaid tax, whichever is the lesser.

The penalty is 20% of the amount of the tax debt. The penalty is 40% of any amount of the debt related to an undisclosed transaction that does not make economic sense or an undisclosed transaction with a foreign financial asset.

The term “negligenza” (neglect) includes situations where a person does not comply with tax laws or does not exercise reasonable care in preparing a tax return. “Negligenza” also includes improper accounting records. You will not have to pay a penalty for negligence if you have a justification for your position. “Negligenza” (neglect) includes any careless, frivolous or deliberate negligence.

You may be held criminally responsible (prosecuted) for the following acts... 1. tax evasion; 2. deliberate failure to file the required information, refusal to pay the due taxes; 3. tax fraud and false statements; or 4. preparation and filing of a false tax return.

This chapter discusses how to pay income tax as you earn or earn income during the year. Generally, federal income tax is paid from current income. There are two ways to pay taxes from current income. 1. Withholding. If you are an employee, your employer will probably withhold income tax from your salary. Taxes may also be withheld from some other income, such as pensions, bonuses, commissions and gambling winnings. The amount withheld is paid to the U.S. Treasury on your behalf. 2.

If you are a resident alien, you must file with your employer a Form W-9 or similar statement under the rules discussed in Chapter 1. If you are a non-resident alien, you must file with your employer a Form 8233 or Form W-8BEN to prove your foreign nationality. You must also provide a Form W-4 to prove that your source of payment is subject to progressive withholding at the same rates as resident aliens or U.S. citizens. If you are a resident alien and receive income other than your wages (such as dividends and royalties) from sources located in the U.S., the taxpayer will generally have to file a Form W-9 or similar statement with the tax agent so that they do not withhold income tax at the rate of 30% (or a lower treaty rate). If you receive the above-mentioned type of income as a non-resident alien, file a Form W-8BEN with the tax agent so that they withhold tax at the rate of 30% (or a lower treaty rate). However, if your income is actually related to professional or commercial activities in the U.S., you must file a Form W-8ECI.

The following withholdings apply to non-resident aliens. Resident aliens are taxed in the same way as U.S. citizens. Wages and other monetary rewards for services performed as an employee are generally subject to progressive withholding at the same rates as resident aliens and U.S. residents. Thus, your refund, unless it is excluded by law from the notion of "wages" or exempt from tax by a treaty, is subject to progressive withholding.

If you are an employee and receive a salary subject to progressive withholding, you must complete Form W-4. Also complete Form W-4 for scholarships if they are payments for past, present or future services for which you do not claim an exemption from withholding under Form 8233 (see below, "Income Eligible for Treaty Benefits"). You must perform the services as an employee and for scholarships (or reduction in tuition). Non-resident foreigners must follow the instructions in Notice 1392 when completing Form W-4 for a refund of money paid to employees who provide services to an employee.
If you are eligible for the benefits under Article 21(2) of the U.S.-India Double Taxation Agreement, you may be entitled to an additional withholding tax in addition to the standard deduction.

If you are a household employee, your employer is not required to withhold income tax. However, you may voluntarily withhold income tax by filing a Form W-4 with your employer. The agreement takes effect when your employer accepts it and begins to withhold income tax. To terminate the agreement, you or your employer must notify the third party of this decision in writing.

If you are an H-2A agricultural worker, your employer is not required to withhold income tax. However, your employer will only withhold income tax if you agree to do so. In this case, you must provide your employer with a properly completed Form W-4. For more information on how to avoid withholding tax, please visit IRS.gov/ForeignAgriculturalWorkers.

As a rule, wages exempted from U.S. income tax under a double taxation treaty are not subject to withholding tax. For information on how to obtain this exemption, see the section "Eligible Income under Tax Treaties" below. Wages paid to foreigners who are residents of American Samoa, Canada, Mexico, Puerto Rico or the U.S. Virgin Islands may be exempted from withholding tax.

If you are a non-resident foreign worker who is a resident of American Samoa or Puerto Rico, the salary for services rendered in American Samoa or Puerto Rico is generally not subject to withholding unless you are an employee of the United States or any of its agencies in American Samoa or Puerto Rico.

Income earned by non-resident aliens who are genuine residents of the U.S. Virgin Islands while working in the United States is not subject to withholding tax, because such persons pay income tax in the U.S. Virgin Islands. To avoid withholding tax on income earned in the United States, genuine residents of the U.S. Virgin Islands must write a letter in two copies to their employers stating that they are genuine residents of the U.S. Virgin Islands and expect to pay tax on all income in the U.S. Virgin Islands.

If you receive pension payments in the United States, they are usually taxed at a rate of 30% (or a lower treaty rate). However, you may withhold progressive rates of tax on the portion of your pension that you began to receive after 1986 for services in the United States. To do so, you must complete Form W-8BEN or Form 8233 and submit it to the tax agent or payer before the income is paid or accrued to you.

Tips you receive during a year for services rendered in the United States are subject to income tax and must be included in your taxable income.lu In addition, tips received while working for a single employer and amounting to $20 or more per month are subject to progressive withholding tax.lu

If you and the person you provide services to do not qualify as an employee and an employer, respectively, your refund is subject to a 30% (or lower contractual rate) withholding tax. However, if you are engaged in a professional or commercial activity in the United States during the tax year, your refund for personal services as an independent contractor (independent contractor services) may be exempt from all or part of the withholding tax if you agree with the IRS on the amount of the required withholding tax. The agreement between you and the IRS regarding the amount of the withholding tax from your refund for personal services as an independent contractor is effective once all parties have agreed upon it. You must agree to file your income tax return for the current tax year on time.

If you are a non-resident foreign artist or non-resident athlete performing or participating in sports events in the United States, you may enter into a Central Withholding Agreement (CWA) with the IRS, provided that certain requirements are met. This agreement will under no circumstances reduce your withholding tax to less than the estimated amount of tax payable. Use Form 13930 to file a CWA for a non-resident artist or non-resident athlete whose gross income in the U.S. for the calendar year was at least $10,000. Form 13930 can be faxed to 866-715-1507 or mailed to the address below. Central Withholding Agreement Program Internal Revenue Service 25520 Commercentre Dr. Lake Forest, CA 92630-8884 We have temporarily waived the income requirement for which form to use to file for a Central Withholding Agreement (CWA). Form 13930-A is currently unavailable. While the waiver is in effect, individuals with income below $10,000 may file for a CWA using Form 13930, “Instructions for Filing a Central Withholding Agreement.” For more information on how to file for a CWA, see Form 13930. For more information, see IRS.gov/Individuals/International-Taxpayers/Central-Withholding-Agreements. A request for a CWA must be received by the IRS at least 45 days before the effective date of the agreement, so that the tour or first performance in the United States is scheduled to begin.

If the information provided is eligible, the IRS will determine the amount of your preliminary income tax for the tax year on gross income actually related to a professional or business activity in the United States. Ordinary and necessary expenses related to the conduct of a business activity may be considered if they meet the requirements of the IRS Commissioner or his/her agent. The Commissioner or his/her agent will send you a letter addressed to the tax agent. This letter will indicate the exempted amount of the final compensation payment and the amount you are eligible to receive as a result of the exemption. You must give two copies of the letter to the tax agent and attach one copy to your income tax return for the tax year for which the exemption applies. For more information, see Publication No. 515.

If you are a network company distributor and have been affected by an erroneous withholding tax, file a U.S. income tax return (Form 1040-NR or Form 1120-F) or, if you have already filed one, a refund claim (Form 1040-X or a supplemented Form 1120-F) to refund the amount of tax withheld in error. In addition, you must attach additional information to your U.S. income tax return or refund claim, including but not limited to the following documents: A copy of your Form W-2, Form 1042-S or Form 1099 to confirm the amount of tax withheld. A statement explaining why the income stated on your Form W-2, Form 1042-S or Form 1099 is not taxable in the U.S. A statement listing all of your dates of entry and exit from the U.S. during the tax year. If compensation is paid over several years, the claim must include all of your dates of entry and exit from the U.S. for each tax year covered by the compensation. Copies of any documents or records indicating the number of days you were in the U.S. in each tax year. A statement containing (a) the number of days (or a smaller unit of time if necessary) you provided individual services in the U.S. related to the recruitment, training and support of your lower-level distributors; and (b) the total number of days (or a smaller unit of time if necessary) you provided individual services regardless of location related to the recruitment, training and support of your lower-level distributors.

For U.S. income tax purposes, green card holders remain resident aliens until their status as legal permanent resident is revoked under immigration laws or by administrative or judicial action. See the Green Card Test section in Chapter 1. If you are a green card holder and your social security payments have been erroneously withheld tax because you have a foreign address, the IRS will refund the withheld tax. To claim a tax refund, you must file Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR. To determine whether you are eligible for a tax refund, send your return to: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service Center Austin, TX 73301 In addition, you must attach the following documents to your Form 1040 or Form 1040-SR. A copy of Form SSA-1042S "Social Security Payments Claim". A copy of your green card. A signed declaration stating: "The U.S. Social Security Administration (SSA) has erroneously withheld income tax on social security payments because I am a legal permanent resident of the United States and my green card has not been cancelled. It has not been terminated by administrative or judicial action. I am filing my U.S. income tax return for the tax year as a resident alien and I report all my income regardless of where I am. I have not claimed benefits for the tax year as a resident of the country, and I have not received any benefits from the U.S. government.

Other income subject to a 30 per cent (or a lower treaty rate) withholding tax is usually fixed or determined income, such as interest (other than on an investment portfolio), dividends, pensions and annuities, as well as income from certain sales and exchange transactions described in chapter 4.

If you are a foreign partner in a U.S. partnership or a foreign corporation, the corporation will withhold tax on your share of the directly related taxable corporation income (ECTI). The corporation in which you are a member may reduce the withholding tax rate on your share of the directly related taxable income by offering certain deductions at the partner level. You will generally need to file Form 8804-C to do so. For more information, see the Form 8804 instructions. Generally, the withholding tax rate on your share of the directly related income is the highest tax rate under Section 1, which is 37%. However, the corporation may withhold tax at the highest rate applicable to a particular type of income that you own if you have provided the corporation with the appropriate documentation. Long-term income from the sale of capital assets is one example of a special type of income to which the highest tax rate applies. Request a refund of the tax withheld as a set-off using Form 1040-NR for 2024. The corporation will provide you with a Form 8805 report showing the amount of the withholding tax.

If you are a direct or indirect foreign partner in a U.S. partnership or a foreign partnership that carries on (or has the status of) a professional or commercial activity in the U.S. and sells your share directly or indirectly in exchange for profits, the recipient of the share transferred after 2017 will generally withhold and pay tax to the IRS on your behalf at a rate of 10% of the amount realized. The rules for withholding and paying this amount are similar to those for selling a real estate share in the U.S. You will be sent Form 8288-A, which will indicate the amount withheld. You can then request a refund of this amount on line 25f of Form 1040-NR as a tax credit on your gains. You can provide the recipient with certain information to reduce the amount withheld or to completely cancel the withholding. For example, if the Tax Code non-recognition provision applies to all the gains received on the share transfer, the recipient does not have to withhold tax if you provide a notice describing the application of the non-recognition provision. If you are a recipient who did not withhold tax, then under Section 1446(f)(4), the partnership is required to withhold tax on your income distribution equal to the amount you did not withhold (plus interest, if applicable). On November 30, 2020, the Department of the Treasury and the Internal Revenue Service approved final regulations by issuing a decision of the Treasury (T.D. 9926 (85 FR 76910)) for the transfer of both shares in a non-PTP partnership (see above) and a PTP partnership under Section 14.

If you are a student or fellow with a non-resident foreigner status and hold an F, J, M or Q visa, and you receive a U.S. grant or scholarship that is not fully exempt from tax, the tax agent (usually the payer of the grant) will withhold tax at a rate of 14% (or the lower treaty rate) on the taxable part of the grant or scholarship that is not a fee for services. However, if you are not a fellow and the grant does not meet certain requirements, tax will be withheld at a rate of 30% (or the lower treaty rate).

If you are in the U.S. for more than one tax year, you must attach a statement to your annual Form W-4 that you have filed an income tax return for the previous year. If you are not in the U.S. for a sufficient amount of time to be required to file, you must attach a statement to your Form W-4 that you are ready to file a tax return when required.

If you provide individual services as an employee or independent contractor and are eligible for exemption from withholding tax on income from the provision of individual services under a double taxation agreement, provide Form 8233 to each tax agent from whom you receive the amounts. Even if you file Form 8233, the tax agent may be required to withhold tax on your income. This is because the factors on which the exemption from taxation under the double taxation agreement is based can only be determined after the end of the tax year. In this case, you must file Form 1040-NR to return the excess tax withheld and provide the IRS with proof that you are eligible for exemption from taxation under the double taxation agreement.

If the required agreement is not listed in the annexes, you must attach a statement in a format similar to that for other agreements. If you have received a student or graduate scholarship and income from the provision of individual services from the same tax agent, use Form 8233 to claim a double taxation agreement exemption for both types of income.

A full 30% withholding tax is required on payments to a non-resident alien or foreign company for income from ticket sales (including television and other) for music festivals, boxing promotions, and other entertainment or sports events, unless the tax agent has been specifically informed otherwise in a letter from the IRS. Depending on the calendar year in which the gross income was received, Form 13930 may be used to request a reduction in the amount of the withholding tax. Withholding tax may be required even if income is not taxable under the provisions of a double taxation agreement. One reason is that partial or full exemption is usually based on factors that can only be determined after the end of the tax year. We have temporarily waived the income requirement for which form to use when filing a Central Withholding Agreement (CWA). Form 13930-A is currently unavailable. While the waiver is in effect, individuals with income below $10,000 may file for a Central Withholding Agreement using Form 13930, “Instructions for Filing a Central Withholding Agreement.” For more information on how to file for a Central Withholding Agreement, see Form 13930. For more information, see IRS.gov/Individuals/International-Taxpayers/Central-Withholding-Agreements. You must pay tax on your departure from the United States on any income for which you have incorrectly claimed a double taxation agreement exemption.

The buyer must file and pay the withholding tax within 20 days of the transfer using Forms 8288. This form must be filed with the IRS along with copies A and B of Form 8288-A. Copy B of this return will be stamped, sent to the IRS and returned to you (the seller) if the return is complete and includes your taxpayer identification number (TIN). You must file Copy B with your tax return to get the withholding tax credit. A stamped copy of Form 8288-A will only be provided to you if your TIN is listed on this form. The IRS will send you a letter requesting your TIN and providing instructions for obtaining it. After you provide your TIN, the IRS will issue you a certified copy of Form 8288-A.

If you are employed in the United States, in most cases you are required to pay taxes to the Social Security Funds and Medicare. By paying these taxes, you contribute to your coverage under the U.S. Social Security System. Coverage includes pension, survivor and disability benefits, and Medicare payments to persons who qualify. In most cases, the first $168,600 of taxable wages received in 2024 for services provided in the United States are subject to Social Security tax. All taxable wages are subject to Medicare tax. Your employer deducts these taxes from each payroll payment. Your employer is required to deduct these taxes on your income tax return if you have multiple employers and the amount withheld from your total 2024 wages exceeds $10,453.20. If one of your employers has made a deduction of more than $10,453.20, you are not eligible for a tax credit for that amount. Contact your employer to request a refund of the excess tax. If your employer does not refund the excess tax, you can file a refund using Form 843. Generally, U.S. Social Security and Medicare taxes apply to wages paid for services provided as an employed person in the United States, regardless of your nationality.

Your employer is responsible for withholding 0.9% (0.009) of the additional Medicare tax on the wages or RRTA compensation that it pays you in excess of $200,000 per calendar year. If you plan to file jointly and assume that your and your spouse's individual wages do not exceed $200,000, but your combined wages and self-employment income exceed $250,000, you may request an additional W-4 withholding and/or make estimated tax payments. If you file Form 1040-NR, you must pay additional Medicare tax if the total of your wages and self-employment income exceeded $125,000 if you are married (you checked the "Married filing separately" box at the top of the first page of Form 1040-NR), or $200,000 if you are a Single or Qualifying surviving spouse (you checked the "Single" or "Qualifying surviving spouse" box at the top of the first page of Form 1040-NR).

If you have received a Medicare supplemental tax incorrectly from your salary, you can claim a credit for it against the total tax liability on your tax return by filing Form 8959 with Form 1040, 1040-SR, or 1040-NR. If you have received a Medicare supplemental tax incorrectly in a previous year for which you have already filed Form 1040, 1040-SR, or 1040-NR, you must file Form 1040-X for the previous year in which you originally received your salary or compensation to claim the Medicare supplemental tax incorrectly withheld. See Form 1040-X instructions.

Non-resident foreigners are not subject to self-employment tax unless an applicable international social security agreement states that they are covered by the U.S. social security system. Residents of the U.S. Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico, Guam, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands (CNMI) or American Samoa are considered U.S. residents for this purpose and are subject to self-employment tax.

If you have both wages and self-employment income, the threshold for applying the additional Medicare tax on self-employment income is reduced (but not reduced to zero) by the amount of wages subject to the additional Medicare tax. Losses from self-employment are not counted for the purposes of this tax. If you file Form 1040-NR, you must pay additional Medicare tax if the total amount of your wages and self-employment income exceeds $125,000 if you are married (you checked the “Married filing separately” box at the top of the first page of Form 1040-NR), or $200,000 if you are an unmarried person or a qualifying surviving spouse (you checked the “Single” or “Qualifying surviving spouse” box at the top of the first page of Form 1040-NR).
If you are required to pay self-employment tax, you can deduct part of the self-employment tax paid when calculating your adjusted gross income.

The United States has entered into social security agreements, commonly referred to as “totalization agreements,” with foreign countries to coordinate the social security coverage and taxation of workers who are employed in part or in full time in one country. Under these agreements, double coverage and double contributions (taxes) for the same work are excluded.

Generally, under these agreements, you pay social security taxes only in the country where you work. However, if you are posted to the same employer in the United States and your salary is normally subject to social security taxes in both countries, most agreements provide that you are only covered by the social security system of the country from which you are posted. To confirm that your salary is subject only to foreign social security taxes and is exempt from U.S. social security taxes (including Medicare tax) under the agreement, you or your employer must request a coverage certificate from the appropriate tax office in the foreign country. This is usually the same office to which you or your employer pay foreign social security taxes. The foreign office will be able to tell you what information is required to issue the certificate. Your employer should keep a copy of the certificate as it may be needed to confirm that you are exempt from U.S. social security taxes. Only wages paid on or after the effective date of the agreement can be exempt from U.S. social security taxes.

Under most treaties, self-employed citizens are covered by the social security system of the country in which they reside. However, under some treaties, you may be exempt from U.S. self-employment tax if you temporarily transfer your business activities to or from the U.S. If you believe your self-employment income is subject only to U.S. self-employment tax and is exempt from foreign social security tax, please request a coverage certificate from the U.S. Social Security Administration. Please follow the link in the Note above. This certificate will confirm your exemption from foreign social security tax. To confirm that your self-employment income is subject only to foreign social security tax and is not subject to U.S. self-employment tax, please request a coverage certificate from the relevant foreign agency.

If your adjusted gross income for 2024 was more than $150,000 (or $75,000 if your 2025 tax status is married and filing separately), replace 110% (1.10) with 100% (1.00) in paragraph (2) above if you are not a farmer or fisherman. Paragraph (2) does not apply if you have not filed a 2024 return.

If you filed your 2024 return on Form 1040-NR and you expect your income and total deductions in 2025 to be about the same, you should use the 2024 return as a guide to completing the Estimated Tax Worksheet in the Form 1040-ES (NR) instructions. If you have not filed your 2024 return, or if your income, deductions, or credits in 2025 will be different, you should calculate those amounts.
If your return is not for a calendar year, the payment dates are the 15th of the 4th, 6th and 9th months of your fiscal year, and the 1st month of the following fiscal year.

Even if you are not required to make a deduction in April or June, your circumstances may change so that you will have to make a deduction later. This may happen if you have additional income or if any of your deductions are reduced or cancelled. In this case, see the Form 1040-ES (NR) instructions and Publication No. 505 for information on how to calculate a deduction.

If after you have paid your deduction, you find that your deduction has increased or decreased significantly due to changes in your income or benefits, you should adjust the remaining deductions. In this case, see the Form 1040-ES (NR) instructions and Publication No. 505.
You will be fined for not paying the deductible tax, except in certain situations.

The Disaster Tax Protection Act 2019 and the Disaster Tax Protection Act 2020 have expanded the special filing rules and procedures for claiming eligible personal accident losses related to certain federally declared disasters in 2018, 2019 and 2020. Eligible accident losses incurred in these tax years can be filed on Form 4684. For more information, see the "Qualifying Disaster Loss" subsection below. Previous versions of Form 4684 can be obtained by clicking on IRS.gov/Form1040X. You may need to file an amended Form 1040-X to claim these benefits on your 2018, 2019 and/or 2020 returns. See the "How to Report a Loss on Form 1040-X" subsection below. Accident and Theft Limitations. If you are an individual, accident losses or theft of personal property not related to a professional or commercial activity or transaction for profit are deductible in 2018-2025, but only if the loss is a result of a natural disaster.

This publication explains the taxation of accidents, thefts and losses of deposits. In an accident, a person’s property is damaged as a result of natural disasters such as hurricanes, fires, car accidents and the like. In a theft, a third party unlawfully appropriates the property of a person. In a loss of deposits, the financial institution in which the person’s deposits are held becomes insolvent or declares bankruptcy. This publication raises the following issues: Definition of accident, theft and loss of deposits. Methods of determining a person’s profit or loss. How to use insurance and other forms of compensation for losses. Limitations on deductions. When and how to report an accident or theft. Special rules for losses in a disaster zone.

Publication No. 584 “Worksheet on Accident, Natural Disaster and Theft (Personal Property)” will help you to list stolen or damaged personal property and determine the amount of the loss. It includes appendices to determine the amount of damage to the home, its interiors and motor vehicles. Publication No. 584-B “Worksheet on Accident, Natural Disaster and Theft in Business” will help you to list stolen or damaged business or income-generating property and determine the amount of the loss.

Accidental losses are deductible in the tax year in which they occurred. However, an accidental loss may be incurred in the year following the loss-causing event. See the subsection "When to report profits and losses" and Table 3 below.

All three types of loss are related to federally declared disasters, but the requirements for each are different. A federally declared disaster is a basis for the President of the United States to grant assistance from the federal government under the Stafford Act. A federally declared disaster includes (a) a declaration of a major natural disaster or (b) a declaration of an emergency under the Stafford Act.

If you suffered an accident or theft of personal property not related to a federally declared disaster, the loss is not a federal accident loss and you are not eligible for a deduction for it, except in special cases.
A natural disaster loss is a loss that is related to a federally declared natural disaster and that is incurred in a district that is eligible for state or individual assistance (or both).

If the amount on line 8 is less than or equal to the amount on line 3, you cannot claim an accidental loss deduction using this provision. If you have filed a claim (or you intend to file a claim) and it is pending, you may receive an income or additional deduction in the following tax year depending on the actual amount of the claim received.
The way in which profits and losses are reported depends on whether the property was commercial, income-generating or personal.
If you are not required to file Form 4797, enter the net profit or loss on your tax return only on the line specified on Form 4797 (for those filing Form 1040, this will be Line 4).

If your losses on business and income-producing property exceed the profits on those types of property, combine your losses on business and income-producing property with the total profits on business and income-producing property. Report the net profit or loss as ordinary profit or loss on Form 4797. If you are not required to file Form 4797, enter the net profit or loss on your tax return only on the line for Form 4797 (for those filing Form 1040, this will be Schedule 1 (Form 1040), Line 4).

If the damaged or stolen property was depreciable property that you owned for more than 1 year, you may have to treat all or part of the gain as ordinary income within the scope of permitted or allowed depreciation.
If you deduct accident or theft losses, you may have a net operating loss (NOL) in the year.
Go to IRS.gov/Account for secure access to your federal tax account information. View your 5-year payment history and any upcoming or scheduled payments.
With an online account, you can access a variety of information that will help you through the filing process.

The quickest and easiest way to get your tax refund is to file online and choose a direct deposit, which provides a secure electronic transfer of your return directly to your financial account. Direct deposit also eliminates the possibility that your check may be lost, stolen, destroyed or returned to the IRS. Eight out of ten taxpayers use the direct deposit method to receive their refund. If you do not have a bank account, go to IRS.gov/DirectDeposit for more information on where to find a bank or credit union that can open an account online.

The following are options for preparing and filing your return online or at your home if you are eligible. Direct File. Direct File is a finally approved software that allows you to file federal individual tax returns online for free and securely. Direct File is suitable for taxpayers from partner states who file relatively simple tax returns that include certain types of income and certain credits and deductions. While you cannot file a state return using Direct File if you live in a partner state, the system will redirect you to state-approved tax software for free state return filing. For more information, updates and answers to frequently asked questions, visit IRS.gov/DirectFile Free File Free File System. This program allows you to prepare and file a federal individual income tax return for free using the software or the Free File fillable forms. However, state tax return filing may not be available through Free File. Visit IRS.gov/FreeFile to find out if you are eligible for free federal tax preparation online, electronic filing, direct contribution or payment options. VITA. The Income Tax Assistance Grant (VITA) program offers free tax assistance to low- and moderate-income individuals, disabled individuals and taxpayers with limited English language skills who need assistance preparing their tax return. Visit IRS.gov/VITA, download the free IRS2Go app, or call 800-906-9887 for information on free tax return filing. TCE. Tax Advice for Seniors
For returns in which an earned income credit (EIC) or an additional child tax credit (ACTC) is claimed, the IRS may not issue a refund before mid-February.

IRS Direct Payment: Pay your individual tax bill or deferred tax payment directly from your deferred or savings account at no cost to you. Debit card, credit card or e-wallet: Choose an approved payment system for online or telephone payments. Electronic Federal Tax Payment: Best for business. Registration required. Check or money transfer: Send your payment by mail to the address provided in the notification or instructions. Cash: You can pay your taxes in cash at any participating store. Same-day delivery: You can also make a same-day transfer from your financial institution. Contact your financial institution to find out about the availability, cost and timing of the service.

Go to IRS.gov/Payments for more information on the options available. Apply for an OPA online (IRS.gov/OPA) to meet your tax obligations through monthly payments if you are unable to pay your taxes in full today.

The Taxpayer Advice Service (TAS) is an independent organization within the U.S. Revenue Service (IRS) that helps taxpayers solve problems after they have contacted the IRS, offers administrative and legislative advice to prevent or remedy problems, and protects taxpayer rights.
If you are a sole proprietorship or a company registered as a partnership or an S-corporation, you can view your tax information and more by opening a company tax account.
Theft of money or property through fraud or deception is considered theft if it is illegal under state or local laws.

If you are eligible for Tax Procedure 2009-20 as amended by Tax Procedure 2011-58, and you choose to follow the procedures described in the guide, you will first need to complete Section C of Form 4684 to determine the amount to be entered in Line 28 of Section B. Skip lines 19-27 and complete lines 29-39 in Section B if necessary.
If you received a refund for a loss in the previous year, you may need to include the amount in the income for the year in which you received the refund.
To claim a tax deduction for accident or theft damages, you must prove that the accident or theft actually occurred. You must also justify the amount you claim as a tax deduction.

You include the taxable part of the insurance payment in the income for the year in which you resume the use of your main residence, or, if the insurance payment is received later, for the year in which you receive the taxable part of the insurance paymentu.
If you calculated your accident or theft loss using the expected refund, you may need to make changes to your tax return for the tax year in which you received the actual refund.

If you later receive a higher amount of refund than you expected after you filed the loss deduction, you may have to include the additional refund in your income for the year in which you received it. However, if any part of the initial deduction did not reduce your tax for the previous year, do not include that part of the refund in your income.
If you later receive exactly the refund you expected to receive, you do not have to include any refund in your income and you will not be able to deduct any additional losses.
If you have received a loss compensation that is greater than the original value of the property, you have made a profit.

There are two ways to claim a tax deduction for an increase in the value of goods sold in the inventory report at the beginning and end of the reporting period. The loss does not need to be re-reported as an accidental or theft loss. If you calculate the loss for an increase in the value of goods sold, you must include any insurance or other compensation you have received in your gross income.

If you have received a theft loss refund, you will need to recalculate the amount of the loss using the lesser of the two values: the original value of the property (see definition below) or the decrease in fair market value between the time immediately before the theft and the time of the return.
Depreciation of your property due to its location in or near the affected area or due to its potential to be affected again is not considered.

Photos taken after an accident will help determine the condition and value of the property after it has been repaired, restored or replaced. For information on appraisals, see the “Appraisal of the amount” subsection above, in the “Calculating the Fair Market Value of Property Items to be Recognized” section.

For a property you buy, your original value is usually the price at which you acquired it. For a property you acquired in another way, such as by inheritance, by gift or in exchange for a tax-free amount, you must determine its original value differently, as explained in Publication No. 551.

If you inherited property from someone who died in 2010 and the beneficiary chose to use the original cost method under section 1022 of the IRS Revenue Code using Form 8939, "Assignment of the Increase in the Original Value of Property Acquired from the Deceased", then special rules apply to the original cost.

Once you have determined the amount of your accident or theft losses, you must determine how much of the loss you can deduct. The deduction for accident and theft losses of personal property is limited. During the tax years 2018 through 2025, individuals’ personal accident and theft losses are deductible only to the extent that they are related to a federally declared natural disaster. Personal accident and theft losses related to a federally declared natural disaster are governed by the $100 rule and the $10% rule, which will be discussed later. The $100 and $10% rules are also summarized in Table 2. There is an exception to the rule that allows accident and theft losses to be deducted only when they are related to a federally declared natural disaster. If you have accident profits, you can deduct accident losses not related to a federally declared natural disaster to the extent that they do not exceed the personal accident profits. Any excess profits are used to reduce losses from a federally declared natural disaster. The 10% rule applies to any remaining federal disaster losses. Losses to commercial property and income-generating property are not covered by these rules. However, if the accident or theft losses are related to a home that you used for business or rented, your deductible loss may be limited. See the Form 4684 instructions, section 10.

In general, events that are closely related in origin result in the same accident. Destruction from two or more closely related causes is considered to be the same accident, for example, destruction from wind and flood caused by the same storm. Two or more objects of property can be damaged as a result of one accident, as in the case of a tornado that damaged both your home and your car parked on the driveway.

If your personal property is stolen, damaged or destroyed in an accident, you must calculate the loss separately for each item of property. Then, combine these individual losses to determine the total loss. Subtract the total loss by $100 and 10% of your adjusted gross income to calculate the loss deduction.

If the property is used partly for personal purposes and partly for commercial or income-generating purposes, the deduction for accidental or theft damages must be calculated separately for the part used for personal purposes and for the part used for commercial or income-generating purposes.
If you have gains from the destruction of your home, you can exclude them from your income as if you had sold or exchanged your home.

Do not report profits if you receive a refund in the form of property that is similar to or equal to the property that was destroyed or stolen. As a rule, you must report profits on the stolen or destroyed property if you have received money or other property as a refund. However, you may defer a report of profits if you acquire a controlling stake (at least 80%) in a corporation that owns property that is similar to or equal to the property.

Under this rule, related persons are, for example, a parent and a child, a brother and a sister, a corporation and an individual holding more than 50% of the shares, and two partnerships in which the same corporation C holds more than 50% of the capital or profits.

If a taxpayer dies after receiving the profit but before purchasing the replacement property, the profit must be reported in the accounts for the year in which the deceased realized the profit. u The executor of the estate or the person who inherits the funds obtained as a result of an accident or theft cannot postpone the reporting of the profits by purchasing the replacement property.

If your gains from the destruction of your main home exceed the amount you can exclude from your income (see the subsection "Main home destroyed" in the section "Calculate your gains") you can defer reporting of all the additional gains, the replacement property must be worth no less than the amount you received from the destruction, less the excluded gains.
You must deduct the original cost of the replacement property (the purchase price) by the amount of the deferred profit. Thus, the profit tax is deferred until you sell the replacement property.

If your destroyed business or income-generating property was located in a federally declared disaster area, any tangible property you acquire for use in your business is considered to be similar to the destroyed property.

You defer reporting of profits from accident or theft by reporting your choice on the tax return for the year in which you made the profits. You receive the profits in the year of receiving insurance or other compensation that results in profits. If the stolen or destroyed property belongs to a partnership or corporation, only the partnership or corporation can decide to defer reporting of profits.u

If you acquire replacement property before filing for the year in which you made the profit, your return must also contain details of all of the following: Replacement property. Deferred profit. Adjustment to historical cost to reflect deferred profit. Any profits that you report as income.

You must file an amended return (individuals use Form 1040-X) for the tax year in which the profit was made in one of the following situations. You do not acquire the replacement property during the required replacement period, subject to the extension. On this amended return, you must report the profits made and pay any additional tax. You acquire the replacement property during the required replacement period, plus the extension, but at a price less than the amount you received for the accident or theft. On this amended return, you must report the portion of the profits that cannot be deferred and pay the additional tax.

If you receive an insurance or other compensation that exceeds the adjusted original value of the property that was destroyed or stolen, you are receiving a profit from the accident or theft. You must include this profit in your income in the year you receive the compensation, u unless you choose to defer reporting profits as explained earlier.

As a rule, you can deduct accidental losses that are not recoverable only in the tax year in which the accident occurred. This statement is true even if you do not repair or replace the damaged property until the following year. (However, see the section "Disaster Area Losses" below for exceptions.) You can deduct theft losses that are not recoverable only in the year in which you discovered that your property was stolen.

This section discusses the special rules that apply to losses related to federally declared disasters. It also provides information on when you can deduct losses, how to file for them, how to deal with a home in a disaster, and what time periods for paying taxes can be extended.
Your home will be considered unsafe only if both of the following conditions apply: After a natural disaster, your home becomes significantly more dangerous than before it.

If the damaged or destroyed property was non-commercial property and you did not include your deductions in the original return, you must first determine whether the accidental loss deduction is beneficial to you.

If your tax preparation professional is unable to do so, you can obtain a copy by filing a Form 4506. A fee is charged for each requested return. However, if your main home, main place of business or tax records are in a federally declared disaster area, no fee will be charged.

Do not include Staffordshire Aid grants in your income if the grant payments were made to help you cover essential expenses or serious needs for medical, dental, housing, personal property, transportation or funeral expenses.

A grant received by an enterprise under a governmental program to compensate enterprises for damage or destruction of property as a result of a natural disaster is not excluded from income under the general welfare exclusion, as a gift, as a related disaster payment (explained below) or as a contribution to capital. However, a company may defer reporting on the profits derived from the grant if it acquires eligible replacement property within a certain period of time. See the section "Deferred Profits" above for the relevant rules.

Relevant disaster mitigation payments made under the Stafford Act or the National Flood Insurance Act (of 15 April 2005) are not included in income. These are payments that you, as a property owner, receive to reduce the risk of damage to your property in the future.

The IRS can defer certain tax dates for taxpayers affected by a federally declared natural disaster. The IRS can defer the filing of income tax, excise tax and employer taxes, and contributions to a traditional IRA (individual retirement account) or a Roth IRA (individual retirement plan).

If the IRS defers a tax deadline, the following taxpayers are eligible for deferral: Any individual whose principal home is in a disaster area (defined later); Any business or sole trader whose principal place of business is in a disaster area; Any individual who is a relief worker associated with a recognized government or charitable organization and who provides relief in a disaster area; Any individual, business or sole trader whose documents are required to meet the deferred tax deadline, provided that those documents are in a disaster area; The principal home or principal place of work does not have to be in a disaster area; Any property or trusted organization that has tax documents required to meet the deferred tax deadline, provided that those documents are in a disaster area; Spouse under joint return with a taxpayer eligible for deferral; Any individual, business or sole trader who is not in a disaster area but whose documents are required to meet the deferred tax deadline are in a disaster area; Any person in a disaster area who has died or been injured as a result of a disaster; Any other person who, in the opinion of the IRS, has been affected by a federally declared disaster.

The year of the disaster is the tax year in which you suffered a loss related to a federally declared disaster. Normally, a loss from a natural disaster occurs in the year in which it occurred. However, a loss from a natural disaster may occur one year after it occurred. For example, if you filed a claim for which there is a reasonable prospect of receiving compensation, no part of the loss for which compensation may be received is deemed to have been incurred until the receipt of compensation is established with reasonable certainty.
If you do so, the loss is treated as if it had been incurred in the previous year. A list of areas requiring state or individual assistance (or both) is available at FEMA.gov/Disaster.

If you have already filed a previous year's return, you can file a disaster loss and reduce your income for that year by filing an amended return. Individuals file an amended return using Form 1040-X (see the "How to file a loss on Form 1040-X" subsection below). To choose this option, complete Part I of Section D of Form 4684 for 2023 and attach it to the 2023 original return or to the amended return that includes the disaster loss deduction. You must make the choice to deduct the loss in the previous year on the day 6 months after the deadline for filing the original return (excluding extensions) for the year of the disaster or earlier. For individuals paying taxes for a calendar year, the deadline for making a decision on the 2024 disaster loss on the 2023 original or amended return is October 15, 2025. For more information on how to report those losses on the 2023 original or amended return, see the instructions for Form 4684 for 2023. If you have filed a disaster loss deduction on your tax return for the year in which the disaster occurred and now choose to deduct that loss on your previous year's return, you must file an amended return to exclude the previously deducted loss on the date of filing (or earlier) of the original or amended return for the previous year that includes the disaster loss deduction.
Complete Part II of Section D of Form 4684 for 2023 if you want to opt out of 2024 for the deduction of a federally declared natural disaster in the previous tax year.

For the standard deduction, the Alternative Minimum Tax adjustment is not retroactive to net qualifying disaster losses. For more information, see the section “Taxpayers who also file the 2024 Form 6251, Alternative Minimum Tax for Individuals” in the Instructions for Form 4684.
If your home is in a federally declared disaster zone, you may defer reporting of the profits if you spend the compensation on repairs or replacement of the home.
If your home is in a federally declared disaster area, your state or local government may require you to demolish or relocate it.
The Earned Income Credit (EIC) is a tax credit for working people whose earned income is less than $63,398. Typically, the tax credit reduces the tax debt.

No. You can qualify for an EIC without a qualifying child if you are at least 25 years old but not older than 65 years old and your earned income is less than $17,640 (or $24,210 for a married couple filing jointly). See Chapter 3.
In addition, your adjusted gross income must be less than one of the above amounts that applies to your situation.

Additional Medicaid Health Care Payments. For information on how Medicaid payments are considered in the context of the EIC, see the Earned Income section. Don't miss out on a state tax credit. If you are married but entitled to file a separate tax return under the special rules for married but separated taxpayers (see Rule 3) and you live in a state with a community of property law, your adjusted gross income includes the portion of your wages and salaries that is required to be included in the gross income.

If you (or your spouse if you file a joint tax return) use an Individual Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN) instead of a Social Security Number, you will not be able to get an EIC. An ITIN is issued by the IRS to non-U.S. citizens who are unable to get a Social Security Number.
If you were a foreign resident at any time during the year, you cannot receive an EIC unless you file a joint tax return.

If you file Form 2555, “Income from Employment Abroad”, you are not eligible for an EIC because you are filing the forms to exclude income from employment abroad from your gross income or to deduct or exclude payments for housing abroad.

If your investment income is less than $11,000, you are eligible for an EIC. If your investment income is more than $11,000, you are not eligible for an EIC. Use the worksheet 1 in this chapter to calculate your investment income.
If you are an employee, your earned income includes all taxable income that you receive from your employer. Rule 15 provides the information you need to calculate your earned income.

If you are a cohabitant under the laws of Nevada, Washington or California, the same rules apply.
U.S. Armed Forces's non-taxable payroll, such as the Combat Payroll, the Basic Housing Allowance (BAH) and the Basic Salary Allowance (BAS), are not considered earned income.
A school may be defined as a primary, middle or high school, a college, a university, a technical driving school or a vocational school.

Your main residence can be anywhere you live permanently. You do not have to have a home in the traditional sense. For example, if your child has lived with you for more than six months in one or more homeless shelters, your child meets the requirements for a residence.
A child is considered to have lived with you for more than half of 2023 if the child was born or died in 2023 and your home was the child's home for more than half of the child's lifetime in 2023.i

If you adopted a child in 2023 and that child was legally handed over to you for legal adoption in 2023, or he/she is a qualifying adoptive child handed over to you during 2023,u the child is deemed to have lived with you for more than half of 2023,u if your primary home was the primary home of that child for more than half of the time that he/she was adopted or placed with you in 2023.

If you and someone else have the same qualifying child, but the other person cannot claim the EIC because he or she is not eligible for it, or his or her earned income or AGI is too high, you may consider the child to be qualifying.

A taxpayer who dies in 2023 meets the age criterion if he was not under 25 years old but under 65 years old.

You are not a qualifying child of another taxpayer (and therefore eligible for an EIC) if the person for whom you meet the criteria of kinship, age, residence and joint tax return is not required to file a tax return and either does not file an income tax return or file a tax return only for a refund of income tax withheld from wages or deductible tax paid.

Your primary home can be anywhere you live permanently. You do not have to have a home in the traditional sense of the word. If you have lived in one or more homeless shelters in the United States for more than half a year, you meet this rule.

Your earned income must be less than: $56,838 ($63,398 for married couples filing jointly) if you have three or more qualifying children with valid SSNs, $52,918 ($59,478 for married couples filing jointly) if you have two qualifying children with valid SSNs, $46,560 ($53,120 for married couples filing jointly) if you have one qualifying child with valid SSNs, or $17,640 ($24,210 for married couples filing jointly) if you have one qualifying child with valid SSNs.
As a rule, earned income is wages, salaries, tips, other remuneration for work subject to taxation, and net profits from self-employment.
